componenttext: Just a question around the working capital move in the first quarter. You've got $400 million, if I'm reading this correctly, of working capital contribution to the cash statement. How do you see that changing as we go through the year? What's behind that move?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had inventory draws in Q1 and we had some turnarounds. We had some inventory reductions that we wanted to do related to the Eagle Point closure. I would say that between now and the end of the year, inventories may come down a little bit. But most of w
componenttext: We had inventory draws in Q1 and we had some turnarounds. We had some inventory reductions that we wanted to do related to the Eagle Point closure. I would say that between now and the end of the year, inventories may come down a little bit. But most of what we wanted to get done for the year, we did in Q1. In Q2 and Q3, they may go up a little bit because of some seasonal trends. But I think there's is a little bit more to go by year end. But most of all, we wanted to accomplish, we are confident in Q1.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: The management of SXL -- you've just become the management of SXL with the changes. I mean is there any change in the strategy there or what's going on in terms of the change that you've made there?
componenttext: The management of SXL -- you've just become the management of SXL with the changes. I mean is there any change in the strategy there or what's going on in terms of the change that you've made there?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No change in strategy. We are still very committed to growing SXL. What we are trying to do though is ensure that as we get that growth, that we don't increase our overhead costs. And we think that there are some opportunities to streamline business proce
componenttext: No change in strategy. We are still very committed to growing SXL. What we are trying to do though is ensure that as we get that growth, that we don't increase our overhead costs. And we think that there are some opportunities to streamline business processes that are to the benefit of both Sunoco Inc. and SXL, reducing some overheads overall in both companies. But the strategy for SXL remains very focused on growth. And Sunoco Inc. believes that there are opportunities between the two companies. But we also are, in Sunoco Inc., very supportive of growth opportunities at SXL that do not depend on Sunoco Inc.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, there were a bunch of things that you were looking for this quarter. I'm just trying to figure out which ones we got, which ones we're still waiting on? I know there's sort of a bit of a laundry list. But if we talk about the proceeds that are rela
componenttext: Brian, there were a bunch of things that you were looking for this quarter. I'm just trying to figure out which ones we got, which ones we're still waiting on? I know there's sort of a bit of a laundry list. But if we talk about the proceeds that are related to the change in the IDR, the sale of the SXL proceeds, the tax rebate, did you get a tax rebate, things like that? Can you just kind of walk us through what the changes were that we all saw in the quarter?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so basically, in Q1 and in the financial statement, is the full impact of the sale of the limited partner units of Sunoco Logistics that we sold, the settlement of the IDR reset, the pension contribution to the Sunoco pension, as well as our tax refu
componenttext: Yes, so basically, in Q1 and in the financial statement, is the full impact of the sale of the limited partner units of Sunoco Logistics that we sold, the settlement of the IDR reset, the pension contribution to the Sunoco pension, as well as our tax refund which was $394 million in which we received at the end of March. What is not excluded, the only item which is not excluded is the $350 million for the sale of the Polypropylene business which was received on April 1. So that cash is not reflected in the balance sheet as of March 31.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the fair sale of Sunoco parent shares for the pension, did that just transfer directly into the pension, so we can actually see a growth for the cash flow statement?
componenttext: So the fair sale of Sunoco parent shares for the pension, did that just transfer directly into the pension, so we can actually see a growth for the cash flow statement?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is correct.
componenttext: That is correct.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: What was your remaining outstanding pension liability that you still have to fund?
componenttext: What was your remaining outstanding pension liability that you still have to fund?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, when we put the shares, we put $90 million approximately of shares into the fund and $140 million of cash, for a total contribution of $230 million.  When we did that, we basically said that we did not expect any legal minimum contributions to need
componenttext: Well, when we put the shares, we put $90 million approximately of shares into the fund and $140 million of cash, for a total contribution of $230 million.  When we did that, we basically said that we did not expect any legal minimum contributions to need to be made until 2012. The equity markets, as you know, have continued to do fairly well since we've done that. So the status of the pension fund is looking better, although I don't have a specific update at the time here.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On your CapEx, it looked like the runrate CapEx for the quarter, particularly on coke, was a little bit light. Can you just talk to that and what we should expect as we move through the balance of the year?
componenttext: On your CapEx, it looked like the runrate CapEx for the quarter, particularly on coke, was a little bit light. Can you just talk to that and what we should expect as we move through the balance of the year?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think our guidance remains for capital. Coke is a little light because they're just starting up the Middletown project. So that will ramp up as we go through the year. Overall, we're sticking with our capital expenditure guidance. We're trying to f
componenttext: Yes, I think our guidance remains for capital. Coke is a little light because they're just starting up the Middletown project. So that will ramp up as we go through the year. Overall, we're sticking with our capital expenditure guidance. We're trying to figure out ways to take cost and spend that money more effectively, and we see a little bit of opportunity there. But nothing at this time to change the guidance that we put out for the year.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you're going to answer this one this time around, but I'll have a go. On Refining, now that we've got Eagle Point out of the system, run rate DD&A and, if you can, maybe some idea of run rate, operating costs, given that utilization's like
componenttext: I don't know if you're going to answer this one this time around, but I'll have a go. On Refining, now that we've got Eagle Point out of the system, run rate DD&A and, if you can, maybe some idea of run rate, operating costs, given that utilization's likely to pick up again?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think, basically, on our guidance, on the Refining is that we want to get the cost structure down to where we can have cash flow breakeven when margins are around the $5 range. I think we're starting to see some progress of the actions we've taken.
componenttext: No. I think, basically, on our guidance, on the Refining is that we want to get the cost structure down to where we can have cash flow breakeven when margins are around the $5 range. I think we're starting to see some progress of the actions we've taken. Our pretax loss improved over $150 million from Q4 to Q1. We're clearly not satisfied that we lost $70 million in Refining in Q1, but we had two major turnarounds underway. And we had an improvement in the results of $150 million versus Q4. So clearly, we're starting to see some benefit from the actions that we took last year. But we've got a lot more to do.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So can you speak to the DD&A, perhaps run rate going forward with just the three refineries?
componenttext: So can you speak to the DD&A, perhaps run rate going forward with just the three refineries?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I  think it's consistent with the guidance that we've given before that for this year, our Refining CapEx is roughly $300 million. We're continue to try to figure out ways to make that more cost effective, but that's kind of our guidance still.
componenttext: No, I  think it's consistent with the guidance that we've given before that for this year, our Refining CapEx is roughly $300 million. We're continue to try to figure out ways to make that more cost effective, but that's kind of our guidance still.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010

componenttextpreview: No. I think the majority of that, Chi, you're going to see in Refining and Supply. It's the large piece of that. A big piece is, of course, related to Eagle Point, the Eagle Point closure.
componenttext: No. I think the majority of that, Chi, you're going to see in Refining and Supply. It's the large piece of that. A big piece is, of course, related to Eagle Point, the Eagle Point closure.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: But you will see, I think, improvements across the board.
componenttext: But you will see, I think, improvements across the board.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in Refining, can you discuss some specific actions you're taking to -- that has resulted in a better margin capture rate on a product side that you showed in the first quarter?
componenttext: And then in Refining, can you discuss some specific actions you're taking to -- that has resulted in a better margin capture rate on a product side that you showed in the first quarter?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: One of the things that we have done is try to simplify the crude slate a bit; still very much looking at where the most optimal crudes to run on the overall basis, but taking perhaps a smaller basket than we had before. And this allows us, I think, to pla
componenttext: One of the things that we have done is try to simplify the crude slate a bit; still very much looking at where the most optimal crudes to run on the overall basis, but taking perhaps a smaller basket than we had before. And this allows us, I think, to plan better, get better reliability and that's one of the areas. Another area, you may recall, is that we have split the product supply piece and the crude supply piece. And the product supply people now are working in a very coordinated fashion, such that we have one phase to the marketplace when we sell our product. And we don't find ourselves inadvertently competing against ourselves to place a product. So I think that has allowed us to optimize some margin capture. We've also done some analytical work around the pricing at terminals and trying to really optimize where we put the volume in the terminals when we have discretionary volumes. So those are some of the kinds of things that we've been doing.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the crude slate side, can you talk about any particular basket of crude that you've eliminated? You mentioned simplifying it. Is there crude form a particular region that you're not taking from anymore?
componenttext: On the crude slate side, can you talk about any particular basket of crude that you've eliminated? You mentioned simplifying it. Is there crude form a particular region that you're not taking from anymore?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that there's a particular region. I think one of the things that -- obviously, the economics and the model are driving us towards not running as much of the heavier -- within the basket that we run, so the heavier part of our basket. And that
componenttext: I don't know that there's a particular region. I think one of the things that -- obviously, the economics and the model are driving us towards not running as much of the heavier -- within the basket that we run, so the heavier part of our basket. And that's economic-driven more than anything.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010

componenttext: Chi, I don't think we really haven't locked that down yet. I mean, we just actually made this decision a couple of days ago. So we've got a little while to figure out the best way to monetize that coal.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010

componenttext: I was wondering if you could help me out on the margin capture rates a little bit. It's obviously going up in the first quarter. But how much of that that you guys think was market related versus kind of actions that you guys took?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a -- I mean, that's a bit of a tough one, I think. We had better results in January and February than we had in March. So I think we are making progress from our own actions, some of which Lynn mentioned. I think the fact that the mark
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a -- I mean, that's a bit of a tough one, I think. We had better results in January and February than we had in March. So I think we are making progress from our own actions, some of which Lynn mentioned. I think the fact that the market was up, obviously helped us a little bit too. But March was pretty tough, with the turnarounds we had underway.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think to be fair, some of the strength in sort of the non-core products that are high-margin products, yes, that we got from the marketplace.
componenttext: I think to be fair, some of the strength in sort of the non-core products that are high-margin products, yes, that we got from the marketplace.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the coke side of the business, I think in your annual report, you talked about opportunities both the fixed and your business in the U.S. You also said broad. I'm wondering if you could elaborate a little bit on what kind of opportunities you guys
componenttext: And on the coke side of the business, I think in your annual report, you talked about opportunities both the fixed and your business in the U.S. You also said broad. I'm wondering if you could elaborate a little bit on what kind of opportunities you guys might have abroad this year?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still in the early business development stages, and steel makers just came out a pretty painful period. So we're starting to have conversations in select places around the world outside of the U.S. about opportunities. And there's really nothi
componenttext: Well, we're still in the early business development stages, and steel makers just came out a pretty painful period. So we're starting to have conversations in select places around the world outside of the U.S. about opportunities. And there's really nothing specific to talk about. But we see some good opportunities there, and we some good interests from steel makers and we're in the early discussions.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the coal production potential expansion, I guess right now, what are your current production costs? And I guess going forward, as you expand the mine, are you envisioning kind of lower production costs because you have more scale? Or would you
componenttext: And then on the coal production potential expansion, I guess right now, what are your current production costs? And I guess going forward, as you expand the mine, are you envisioning kind of lower production costs because you have more scale? Or would you have kind of similar production costs?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not going to disclose our production costs and we have to sell the coal too. But we think the cost will be a little bit higher than what we currently bring out, but not necessarily in a material way. And in some of the places where we may take
componenttext: Well, we're not going to disclose our production costs and we have to sell the coal too. But we think the cost will be a little bit higher than what we currently bring out, but not necessarily in a material way. And in some of the places where we may take out the coal, the royalties maybe a little bit higher, given the tick up in prices. So we've had this project on the drawing board for little while, and we just waited until we were comfortable with coal prices and the outlook that we felt that it could be a good economic project.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, with all the asset sales that you guys have going on and the tax refund, it seems like you guys are going to build a decent cash pointed to the end of the year. I guess, what do you guys envision -- how do you guys envision spending tha
componenttext: And then, I guess, with all the asset sales that you guys have going on and the tax refund, it seems like you guys are going to build a decent cash pointed to the end of the year. I guess, what do you guys envision -- how do you guys envision spending that cash? Is that more to protect your balance sheet? Or is that to make kind of a strategic -- being in a position to do something towards the end of the year?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we have already built a pretty sizable cash balance already. And I think first and foremost, we're thinking about protecting the balance sheet and the capital program. And last year was a pretty painful year for the company and for the bala
componenttext: Well, I think, we have already built a pretty sizable cash balance already. And I think first and foremost, we're thinking about protecting the balance sheet and the capital program. And last year was a pretty painful year for the company and for the balance sheet. So I think first and foremost, it's to protect the balance sheet until we're comfortable that we're through the Refining down cycle. We're interested in growing parts of our business, the Retail business, the Logistics business. We've got a big project in coke to build and fund this year. So we see opportunities to put the capital to work. If we can find the right acquisitions or opportunities, we'll put the capital to work, at the same time protecting the balance sheet and making sure we get through the downturn.

componenttext: Jeff, I think, it's a little early for us to talk about that. I think we're working through exactly when, what rate the coal would come out of the mine in '11. And we haven't given guidance for '11. So I think it's a little early for us to really get into that.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I'm really just trying to get a sensitivity, so that I can order this, pricing and spot pricing and adjust as we go through time. So it's not really as much guidance as it is a way to compare 2010 to the current market in however it may evolve. And on
componenttext: And I'm really just trying to get a sensitivity, so that I can order this, pricing and spot pricing and adjust as we go through time. So it's not really as much guidance as it is a way to compare 2010 to the current market in however it may evolve. And one influence that might have on your coke profitability?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Clare. The sensitivity that we've generally given on coal prices is for every $25 per ton change in the price would affect our EBITDA, about $40 million, and our net income, $20 million to $25 million. That's probably all we could give you t
componenttext: Jeff, this is Clare. The sensitivity that we've generally given on coal prices is for every $25 per ton change in the price would affect our EBITDA, about $40 million, and our net income, $20 million to $25 million. That's probably all we could give you there. And you can try to gauge where the spot prices where when we contracted it as best you can.

componenttext: No. I think we're always looking at our portfolio and thinking about our portfolio. But other than the retail assets that we've been explicit about, there's nothing more to really add today.

componenttext: I'm truly impressed with the performance of the Refining side. I guess though, I feel like I'm missing something. Because in a period where you had extensive conversion unit turns in probably the wrong month and the quarter for them to occur, $1.80 to $1 a barrel LIFO hit, low utilization rates, it seems there has to be something else going on to hold your unit cost down to the level that I roughly calculate and not to produce an adverse margin effect. And you had the five-day crude pricing lag, which had to hurt you additionally in the period. What am I missing?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think know that you're missing anything.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say, Mark -- one thing I'll tell you there is that, on the [indiscernible] (01:44:07) point, it is under -- the timing was kind of offset by some benefit. We add just ratability during the quarter. Usually, we're very ratable the way we purchase
componenttext: Yes, I'd say, Mark -- one thing I'll tell you there is that, on the [indiscernible] (01:44:07) point, it is under -- the timing was kind of offset by some benefit. We add just ratability during the quarter. Usually, we're very ratable the way we purchase crude, just happen to be some benefit. So it wasn't as big as a hit you would like. But all totaled, outside of the turnaround, we had a significantly improved margin capture. And there were several aspects of that, that was the way we operated in our conversion units and yield gains. It was the one Lynn talked about earlier, in terms of actual realizations on our benchmark products, some help on our chemicals products out of the refinery. There is also a lift we got from after the Eagle Point closure in terms of our production mix.

componenttext: Hello. My name is Dawn, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the first quarter 2010 earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Lynn Elsenhans, Chairman and CEO of Sunoco. Please go ahead.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good evening. Welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call where we will be discussing the company's first quarter earnings call that we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McG
componenttext:
Thank you, and good evening. Welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call where we will be discussing the company's first quarter earnings call that we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McGrory, our Manager of Investor Relations. I'll start by making a few introductory comments and then Brian will address business results and comment on our overall financial position. As part of today's call, I will direct you to our website, www.sunocoinc.com, where we have posted number presentation slides which may provide a useful reference as we progress through the remarks. I'd also refer you to the Safe Harbor statement referenced in Slide #2 of the slide package, and as included in this afternoon's earnings release. So let's begin. 
As you can see from Slides 3 and 4, we reported quarterly net income, excluding special items of $17 million or $0.14 a share. These results reflect the market environment that remains very challenging, particularly for the Refining and Chemicals businesses which are still under significant pressure due to low demand and excess global supply. That said, during the quarter, we continue to take aggressive actions to address those issues within our control, and we are seeing the benefits of these actions in our results. 
Our first quarter Refining benchmark margins improved from the prior quarter. And we made progress in improving our Refining margin captured during the period that was challenged with low utilization due to two planned turnarounds at our Marcus Hook and Toledo refineries. We successfully completed both turnarounds in a safe manner, and are focused on running the refineries at optimal utilization rates for the remainder of the year. 
Excluding the discontinued Polypropylene business, our non-Refining businesses earned $78 million in the first quarter versus $49 million for the same quarter in 2009, which is largely due to good execution and a sharp focus on cost. Retail Marketing earned $21 million in the first quarter of 2010. Logistics earned $17 million with steady contributions from Sunoco Logistics Partners LP and our Coke segment earned $37 million. 
Our sharp focus on achieving a competitive cost structure continues this year. Cash, operating expenses, excluding fuel, utilities and the polypropylene operations that were sold in the first quarter were more than $50 million lower sequentially in the first quarter of this year versus the fourth quarter of 2009. This expense measurement basis is used internally to track our progress in reducing our controllable expenses, and demonstrates our efforts and success in driving our costs to a competitive level. 
As we consider the outlook for the remainder of 2010, we continue to expect the challenging market for petroleum and chemical products due to ongoing economic weakness and excess global supply. However, Sunoco is well prepared. The early proactive steps we took during this cycle have made us stronger, leaner and more competitive. We continue to drive toward a sustainably lower cost structure, and are focused on running our refineries safely, reliably at optimal capacity utilization, lowering our break even costs per barrel and improving margin capture, all of which are designed to increase our cash generation through operations. 
Our recent actions to strengthen our balance sheet have enabled us to maintain financial flexibility, and position us to take advantage of attractive growth opportunities at our Logistics, Retail Marketing and Coke businesses. One such opportunity that we can announce today is a plan that was recently approved by management to expand production at our Jewell coal mining facility. Brian will talk about this in a bit more detail shortly. 
We are also pleased to announce that we started construction at our Middletown coke plant in early April. We have already signed an agreement with AK Steel in which they have agreed to purchase, over a 20-year period, all of the coke and available electrical power from this facility. Completion of the plant and it's first coke production is estimated for the second half of 2011. Now let me turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly net income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported a net loss of $63 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in Q1, which included $80 million of net unfavorable special i
componenttext:
Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly net income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported a net loss of $63 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in Q1, which included $80 million of net unfavorable special items, as detailed in our earnings release and on Slide 5 of our web deck. 
We recorded a $44 million after-tax loss related to the divestment of the discontinued Polypropylene operations, as well as a $20 million after-tax provision for contract losses in connection with excess barge capacity resulting from the shutdown of Eagle Point refining operations. We also incurred additional charges totaling $16 million after-tax, associated with pension settlement losses and unfavorable deferred state income tax adjustments attributable to the continuing phenol operations. 
Before addressing some specifics regarding operating performance, let me just say that quarterly results, particularly for Refining, generally reflect a continuation of market weakness. While crack spreads improved from the fourth quarter, they remained depressed particularly in the Mid-Continent region. We were further challenged in Refining during the first quarter due to planned turnaround activity at two of our refineries, with significantly reduced utilization during the month of March. 
Our non-Refining operations however, continued to make positive contributions, generating returns consistent with the fourth quarter, excluding discontinued operations and the $41 million onetime tax credit that we've received in Q4. Additionally, the success of our actions to lower cost is reflected in our results. We have made some progress on margin capture, and we continue to pursue initiatives to improve our cost structure as financial positioning for the future. 
Regarding first quarter business unit results, I direct you to Slide 6. Refining and Supply had a $70 million pretax loss or $42 million after-tax in the first quarter of 2010, compared to a pretax loss of $226 million in Q4 or $135 million after-tax in Q4. While we are not satisfied with our Refining performance in the first quarter, we believe the $156 million pretax improvement sequentially versus the fourth quarter, especially in light of the two turnarounds we had underway in the first quarter, demonstrates that the actions we have taken to improve our Refining performance are beginning to yield results. 
Market margins improved from the prior quarter, and we made progress on both margin capture and cost reduction initiatives. But the planned turnarounds resulted in reduced utilizations and prevented us from covering all of our fixed costs. Operationally, crude unit utilization across the system in the first quarter was 79%. 
Before we talk in more detail about our first quarter 2010 margin realization, I would like to call your attention to a few changes that we've made to our benchmark margins, essentially, to make them more reflective of our market. These adjustments included an increase in our crude transportation cost and the addition of a jet component to our Toledo benchmark. The updated benchmarks are detailed on Slide 23. The changes do not affect comparability of realizations, as historical benchmarks have either been reinstated in the case of crude transportation costs or not materially different as a result of the change, as was the case with the addition of the Toledo jet component. 
With respect to our Q1 margin realizations, I refer you to Slide 7 and 8 for more detail on our Refining system crude costs and product differentials versus our benchmark. Our results generally reflect improvement in the first quarter versus recent quarters due largely to improved product realizations, with offsets in higher crude transportation rates and the impact of LIFO reserves. 
Even with the challenges that the turnarounds presented in achieving ratable sales and managing inventory, we did see improvements in capturing more of the benchmark margin as compared to last quarter, in particular, during the early part of the quarter and before the turnaround activity in March. While most of the factors that affect our realizations versus our benchmarks are typically market related, we continue to aggressively take actions on identified opportunities to improve our margin realizations versus benchmark margins, and we are seeing some early positive results. 
In general, our benchmarks are up approximately $2 per barrel on average from the fourth quarter of 2009, and our realized margins are also higher by about $2 per barrel. Our crude costs for the quarter averaged about $0.90 per barrel above our weighted benchmark, due to higher transportation costs and the impact of LIFO reserves. Our crude inventories fell significantly during the quarter and we reserved for these draws at the higher quarter end crude prices. By year-end, we are still expecting to have permanent draws of crude oil and refined product inventory related to our Eagle Point closure. But we are conservatively deferring recognition of any profit related to these draws in the event that other business drivers result in inventory builds that might offset these draws. 
On the product said, our average differential was approximately $0.67 per barrel, lower than our weighted benchmark. The product differentials were challenged in March during the turnarounds due largely to the lower yield gains and the costs of reserving for refined product inventory draws at higher quarter end pricing. The turnaround activity also impact the ratability of sales and hence, realized margins, particularly in Toledo where our benchmark margins were significantly better in March versus the rest of the quarter. 
As compared to the fourth quarter, average realizations on benchmark products in the first quarter were still improved even with the lower utilization in March. We successfully completed our planned cat cracker turnaround in Marcus Hook which limited production during all of March.  Additionally, the Toledo hydrocracker turnaround impacted production for a few weeks in March and was successfully completed in mid-April. Now that we have completed the turnarounds, we have the capacity to operate at or above 90% utilization in the Northeast. 
Now let's turn to our Non-refining businesses which continued to contribute positive results. Our Retail, Marketing, Logistics and Coke businesses earned $75 million after-tax in aggregate during the quarter as detailed on Slide 9. 
Retail Marketing earned $21 million in the first quarter of 2010. Retail gasoline margins remained fairly consistent with the prior quarter but sales volumes were lower, a decline consistent with DOE statistics and attributable to poor weather conditions in the Northeast. During the quarter, we also continue to execute in our Retail Portfolio Management program and, generated approximately $8 million of proceeds and $3 million of after-tax gains on site sales through the sale of 16 sites, primarily to Sunoco branded dealers and distributors. Approximately 80% of the sites divested continue to be in the Sunoco dealer or distribution portfolio. We will continue to use this program to enhance our overall return on capital employed in the retail business. We anticipate that an additional $50 million of proceeds will be generated through 2011. 
Turning to the Logistics business, we earned $17 million in Q1. We continue to believe we have very positive growth opportunities for the Logistics business. 
Now turning to the Coke business. Coke posted another solid contribution, earning $37 million in Q1 consistent with our guidance. We have been in startup mode at our Granite City Coke facility through the first quarter of 2010. As we discussed on Slide 10, at this time, we continue to work through some challenges within the operations that have caused our ramp up to be slower than planned. We're making the necessary adjustments so that we can run the plant as designed at full charge rate. At this time, however, we maintain our full-year guidance of SunCoke net income between $125 million to $140 million, as we expect some benefit from coal pricing at lower cost to offset the negative impact of a slower than planned ramp up in the Granite City operations. 
We also have a few more positive updates related to the SunCoke business that Lynn referenced earlier. We have started construction at our Middletown plant, and look forward to our first coke production from that plant occurring in the second half of 2011. Also as Lynn referenced earlier, we would like to announce our plans to expand our coal production at our Jewell mining facility. We plan to increase our production of our high-quality mid-vol coal at our Jewell mining facility by approximately 500,000 tons per year. We believe that our plan provides the company with an opportunity for income growth. We would initiate the project in the current quarter starting with the training of new minors. Under this plan, we expect to see increased production of coal starting in January of 2011, ramping up to our target production rate for the whole facility of 1.75 million annualized tons by the end of 2012. 
The required capital for the project is projected to be approximately $25 million, with the majority of capital spend occurring in 2011 and 2012. Using conservative estimates of coal prices relative to the current market, we anticipate a slightly negative impact to income in 2010 and '11 from the expansion project due to the cost of training new minors, with positive impact to income starting in 2012. If the coal markets continue to improve, we may see benefit from the increased production earlier and conversely, we may see less benefit from coal sales if the coal market declines. 
Lastly, we have recently initiated a study to update our measure of coal reserves at our Jewell mining facility. 
Turning to our Chemicals business, to close out our discussion on Non-refining results, as announced earlier this month, we successfully closed upon the sale of our Polypropylene business on March 31, for approximately $350 million in net proceeds which were received in early April. As a result, the results of our Polypropylene business are showing as discontinued operations in the first quarter. These results reflect some improvement in margins and lower costs as compared to the fourth quarter, and also benefit from LIFO inventory profits due to inventory draws. 
Finally, let me take a few minutes to discuss our financial position at the end of March. In conjunction with that, I direct you to Slide 11 and 12. From a fund flow perspective, our first-quarter net cash flow before debt activity was a positive $449 million, largely driven by the receipt of a tax refund of approximately $394 million related to net loss carrybacks. Additionally in February, Sunoco Logistics issued $500 million of senior notes to fund the previously announced incentive distribution exchange transaction with Sunoco, as well is to out pay outstanding borrowings under the Sunoco Logistics revolving credit facility.  
From a balance sheet perspective, our overall net debt position was $1.6 billion, down about $500 million from the fourth quarter. Of the $1.6 billion net debt position, approximately $1.1 billion of net debt was attributable to Sunoco Logistics, leaving approximately $500 million of net debt attributable to Sunoco at the parent level, which does not reflect the impact of the cash from the Polypropylene sale. 
We ended the quarter with a consolidated net debt-to-capital ratio of 34%. However, at the Sunoco level, excluding Sunoco Logistics, we ended the quarter with a consolidated net debt-to-total capital of 16%. From a liquidity perspective, at March 31, we had $812 million of cash and approximately $1.9 billion of available committed borrowing capacity, which includes approximately $414 million available for Sunoco Logistics. As I mentioned earlier, the cash balance at quarter end does not include the $350 million of proceeds from the sale of the Chemicals Polypropylene business as those cash proceeds were received in early April. 
And a final balance sheet note. At March 31 current replacement cost of all inventories valued at LIFO exceeds their carrying value by $2.8 billion. As we look forward to the remainder of 2010, we will continue to take appropriate actions that will assist us in maintaining our financial flexibility. To build a better Sunoco for the future and to deliver value to shareholders, we remain focused on the fundamentals, running our refinery safely and reliably at optimal capacity utilization, lowering our break even cost per barrel and improving margin capture. This focus will help us achieve our aspiration of becoming the preferred provider of transportation fuels in our markets. With that, I'll ask the operator to open up the lines for any questions.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question on coke and on the Jewell mine expansion. Does the expanded production scale in over some period of time or you expect that to be kind of a chunky late 2012 event? And then a follow on, as you consider your non-core asset disposal program, is t
componenttext: A question on coke and on the Jewell mine expansion. Does the expanded production scale in over some period of time or you expect that to be kind of a chunky late 2012 event? And then a follow on, as you consider your non-core asset disposal program, is the mine within this category? And are you able to sell that coal mine under the existing contract with the Jewell plant or is there some renegotiation that would be involved with that?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Evan, I'll start with the second question first. At this time, we don't intend to sell the coal mine and we think that's a good asset. We're going to put some capital into it and expand the coal that we take out of the ground there. So at this time, that'
componenttext: Evan, I'll start with the second question first. At this time, we don't intend to sell the coal mine and we think that's a good asset. We're going to put some capital into it and expand the coal that we take out of the ground there. So at this time, that's our plan with regard to the coal mine. With regard to the timing of the coal, it will start to come out in stages starting in 2011. One of the things that we're going to be very focused on is hiring miners in advance of that, getting the right training and making sure that we have a ramp-up that works pretty well. And it will be complete with 500,000 tons of additional capacity by the end of 2012.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question is the great improvement in SG&A from 4Q to 1Q, $19 million lower, $21 million over kind of an average period. Is this an impact from your cost cutting with a lower run rate going forward? And can you give us any kind of color there, wh
componenttext: My second question is the great improvement in SG&A from 4Q to 1Q, $19 million lower, $21 million over kind of an average period. Is this an impact from your cost cutting with a lower run rate going forward? And can you give us any kind of color there, what it's in that cut?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think one of the measures that Lynn mentioned in her remarks and a measure that we're using internally for our own performance measures as well as for our executive compensation structure, is basically measuring cash expenses excluding fuel and uti
componenttext: Yes, I think one of the measures that Lynn mentioned in her remarks and a measure that we're using internally for our own performance measures as well as for our executive compensation structure, is basically measuring cash expenses excluding fuel and utilities, so really getting at the cash expenses of the company. And as Lynn mentioned in her remarks, those are down $50 million in Q1 versus Q4. That's the primary measure that we have. And I think everyone knows we're pretty focused on cost and cost reductions. So we built these from timing as we go through the year, there's seasonality on some items. So expenses won't necessarily -- they may go up and down at times a little bit but fundamentally, we're focused on cost reductions.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Edward Westlake with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Edward Westlake with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question around the working capital move in the first quarter. You've got $400 million, if I'm reading this correctly, of working capital contribution to the cash statement. How do you see that changing as we go through the year? What's behind that
componenttext: Just a question around the working capital move in the first quarter. You've got $400 million, if I'm reading this correctly, of working capital contribution to the cash statement. How do you see that changing as we go through the year? What's behind that move?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had inventory draws in Q1 and we had some turnarounds. We had some inventory reductions that we wanted to do related to the Eagle Point closure. I would say that between now and the end of the year, inventories may come down a little bit. But most of w
componenttext: We had inventory draws in Q1 and we had some turnarounds. We had some inventory reductions that we wanted to do related to the Eagle Point closure. I would say that between now and the end of the year, inventories may come down a little bit. But most of what we wanted to get done for the year, we did in Q1. In Q2 and Q3, they may go up a little bit because of some seasonal trends. But I think there's a little bit more to go by year end. But most of what we wanted to accomplish, we are confident in Q1.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: The management of SXL -- you've just become the management of SXL with the changes. I mean is there any change in the strategy there or what's going on in terms of the change that you've made there?
componenttext: The management of SXL -- you've just become the management of SXL with the changes. I mean is there any change in the strategy there or what's going on in terms of the change that you've made there?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No change in strategy. We are still very committed to growing SXL. What we are trying to do though is ensure that as we get that growth, that we don't increase our overhead costs. And we think that there are some opportunities to streamline business proce
componenttext: No change in strategy. We are still very committed to growing SXL. What we are trying to do though is ensure that as we get that growth, that we don't increase our overhead costs. And we think that there are some opportunities to streamline business processes that are to the benefit of both Sunoco Inc. and SXL, reducing some overheads overall in both companies. But the strategy for SXL remains very focused on growth. And Sunoco Inc. believes that there are opportunities between the two companies. But we also are, in Sunoco Inc., very supportive of growth opportunities at SXL that do not depend on Sunoco Inc.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have a question from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, there were a bunch of things that you were looking for this quarter. I'm just trying to figure out which ones we got, which ones we're still waiting on? I know there's sort of a bit of a laundry list. But if we talk about the proceeds that are rela
componenttext: Brian, there were a bunch of things that you were looking for this quarter. I'm just trying to figure out which ones we got, which ones we're still waiting on? I know there's sort of a bit of a laundry list. But if we talk about the proceeds that are related to the change in the IDR, the sale of the SXL proceeds, the tax rebate, did you get a tax rebate, things like that? Can you just kind of walk us through what the changes were that we all saw in the quarter?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so basically, in Q1 and in the financial statement, is the full impact of the sale of the limited partner units of Sunoco Logistics that we sold, the settlement of the IDR reset, the pension contribution to the Sunoco pension, as well as our tax refu
componenttext: Yes, so basically, in Q1 and in the financial statement, is the full impact of the sale of the limited partner units of Sunoco Logistics that we sold, the settlement of the IDR reset, the pension contribution to the Sunoco pension, as well as our tax refund which was $394 million in which we received at the end of March. What is not excluded, the only item which is not excluded is the $350 million for the sale of the Polypropylene business which was received on April 1. So that cash is not reflected in the balance sheet as of March 31.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the fair sale of Sunoco parent shares for the pension, did that just transfer directly into the pension, so we can actually see a growth for the cash flow statement?
componenttext: So the fair sale of Sunoco parent shares for the pension, did that just transfer directly into the pension, so we can actually see a growth for the cash flow statement?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is correct.
componenttext: That is correct.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: What was your remaining outstanding pension liability that you still have to fund?
componenttext: What was your remaining outstanding pension liability that you still have to fund?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, when we put the shares, we put $90 million approximately of shares into the fund and $140 million of cash, for a total contribution of $230 million.  When we did that, we basically said that we did not expect any legal minimum contributions to need
componenttext: Well, when we put the shares, we put $90 million approximately of shares into the fund and $140 million of cash, for a total contribution of $230 million.  When we did that, we basically said that we did not expect any legal minimum contributions to need to be made until 2012. The equity markets, as you know, have continued to do fairly well since we've done that. So the status of the pension fund is looking better, although I don't have a specific update at the time here.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On your CapEx, it looked like the run rate CapEx for the quarter, particularly on coke, was a little bit light. Can you just talk to that and what we should expect as we move through the balance of the year?
componenttext: On your CapEx, it looked like the run rate CapEx for the quarter, particularly on coke, was a little bit light. Can you just talk to that and what we should expect as we move through the balance of the year?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think our guidance remains for capital. Coke is a little light because they're just starting up the Middletown project. So that will ramp up as we go through the year. Overall, we're sticking with our capital expenditure guidance. We're trying to f
componenttext: Yes, I think our guidance remains for capital. Coke is a little light because they're just starting up the Middletown project. So that will ramp up as we go through the year. Overall, we're sticking with our capital expenditure guidance. We're trying to figure out ways to take cost and spend that money more effectively, and we see a little bit of opportunity there. But nothing at this time to change the guidance that we put out for the year.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you're going to answer this one this time around, but I'll have a go. On Refining, now that we've got Eagle Point out of the system, run rate DD&A and, if you can, maybe some idea of run rate, operating costs, given that utilization's like
componenttext: I don't know if you're going to answer this one this time around, but I'll have a go. On Refining, now that we've got Eagle Point out of the system, run rate DD&A and, if you can, maybe some idea of run rate, operating costs, given that utilization's likely to pick up again?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think, basically, on our guidance, on the Refining is that we want to get the cost structure down to where we can have cash flow breakeven when margins are around the $5 range. I think we're starting to see some progress of the actions we've taken.
componenttext: No. I think, basically, on our guidance, on the Refining is that we want to get the cost structure down to where we can have cash flow breakeven when margins are around the $5 range. I think we're starting to see some progress of the actions we've taken. Our pretax loss improved over $150 million from Q4 to Q1. We're clearly not satisfied that we lost $70 million in Refining in Q1, but we had two major turnarounds underway. And we had an improvement in the results of $150 million versus Q4. So clearly, we're starting to see some benefit from the actions that we took last year. But we've got a lot more to do.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So can you speak to the DD&A, perhaps run rate going forward with just the three refineries?
componenttext: So can you speak to the DD&A, perhaps run rate going forward with just the three refineries?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I  think it's consistent with the guidance that we've given before that for this year, our Refining CapEx is roughly $300 million. We're continue to try to figure out ways to make that more cost effective, but that's kind of our guidance still.
componenttext: No, I  think it's consistent with the guidance that we've given before that for this year, our Refining CapEx is roughly $300 million. We're continue to try to figure out ways to make that more cost effective, but that's kind of our guidance still.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Chi Chow with Macquarie Capital.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Chi Chow with Macquarie Capital.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lynn, you mentioned the $50 million in cost reduction, 1Q versus Q4. Do you have a breakout of that by business segment?
componenttext: Lynn, you mentioned the $50 million in cost reduction, 1Q versus Q4. Do you have a breakout of that by business segment?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think the majority of that, Chi, you're going to see in Refining and Supply. It's the large piece of that. A big piece is, of course, related to Eagle Point, the Eagle Point closure.
componenttext: No. I think the majority of that, Chi, you're going to see in Refining and Supply. It's the large piece of that. A big piece is, of course, related to Eagle Point, the Eagle Point closure.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: But you will see, I think, improvements across the board.
componenttext: But you will see, I think, improvements across the board.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in Refining, can you discuss some specific actions you're taking to -- that has resulted in a better margin capture rate on the product side that you showed in the first quarter?
componenttext: And then in Refining, can you discuss some specific actions you're taking to -- that has resulted in a better margin capture rate on the product side that you showed in the first quarter?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: One of the things that we have done is try to simplify the crude slate a bit; still very much looking at where the most optimal crudes to run on the overall basis, but taking perhaps a smaller basket than we had before. And this allows us, I think, to pla
componenttext: One of the things that we have done is try to simplify the crude slate a bit; still very much looking at where the most optimal crudes to run on the overall basis, but taking perhaps a smaller basket than we had before. And this allows us, I think, to plan better, get better reliability and that's one of the areas. Another area, you may recall, is that we have split the product supply piece and the crude supply piece. And the product supply people now are working in a very coordinated fashion, such that we have one phase to the marketplace when we sell our product. And we don't find ourselves inadvertently competing against ourselves to place a product. So I think that has allowed us to optimize some margin capture. We've also done some analytical work around the pricing at terminals and trying to really optimize where we put the volume in the terminals when we have discretionary volumes. So those are some of the kinds of things that we've been doing.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the crude slate side, can you talk about any particular basket of crude that you've eliminated? You mentioned simplifying it. Is there crude from a particular region that you're not taking from anymore?
componenttext: On the crude slate side, can you talk about any particular basket of crude that you've eliminated? You mentioned simplifying it. Is there crude from a particular region that you're not taking from anymore?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that there's a particular region. I think one of the things that -- obviously, the economics and the model are driving us towards not running as much of the heavier -- within the basket that we run, so the heavier part of our basket. And that
componenttext: I don't know that there's a particular region. I think one of the things that -- obviously, the economics and the model are driving us towards not running as much of the heavier -- within the basket that we run, so the heavier part of our basket. And that's economic-driven more than anything.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Jewell expansion, the 500,000 tons of increased coal production, is that targeted at third party sales? Or is it more for internal supply to your coal plants?
componenttext: On the Jewell expansion, the 500,000 tons of increased coal production, is that targeted at third party sales? Or is it more for internal supply to your coal plants?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chi, I don't think we really haven't locked that down yet. I mean, we just actually made this decision a couple of days ago. So we've got a little while to figure out the best way to monetize that coal.
componenttext: Chi, I don't think we really haven't locked that down yet. I mean, we just actually made this decision a couple of days ago. So we've got a little while to figure out the best way to monetize that coal.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Faisel Khan with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Faisel Khan with Citigroup.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could help me out on the margin capture rates a little bit. It's obviously going up in the first quarter. But how much of that, that you guys think was market related versus kind of actions that you guys took?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could help me out on the margin capture rates a little bit. It's obviously going up in the first quarter. But how much of that, that you guys think was market related versus kind of actions that you guys took?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a -- I mean, that's a bit of a tough one, I think. We had better results in January and February than we had in March. So I think we are making progress from our own actions, some of which Lynn mentioned. I think the fact that the mark
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a -- I mean, that's a bit of a tough one, I think. We had better results in January and February than we had in March. So I think we are making progress from our own actions, some of which Lynn mentioned. I think the fact that the market was up, obviously, helped us a little bit too. But March was pretty tough, with the turnarounds we had underway.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think to be fair, some of the strength in sort of the non-core products that are high-margin products, yes, that we got from the marketplace.
componenttext: I think to be fair, some of the strength in sort of the non-core products that are high-margin products, yes, that we got from the marketplace.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the coke side of the business, I think in your annual report, you talked about opportunities both to expand your business in the U.S. and you also said abroad. I'm wondering if you could elaborate a little bit on what kind of opportunities you guys
componenttext: And on the coke side of the business, I think in your annual report, you talked about opportunities both to expand your business in the U.S. and you also said abroad. I'm wondering if you could elaborate a little bit on what kind of opportunities you guys might have abroad this year?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still in the early business development stages, and steel makers just came out of a pretty painful period. So we're starting to have conversations in select places around the world outside of the U.S. about opportunities. And there's really no
componenttext: Well, we're still in the early business development stages, and steel makers just came out of a pretty painful period. So we're starting to have conversations in select places around the world outside of the U.S. about opportunities. And there's really nothing specific to talk about. But we see some good opportunities there, and we some good interests from steel makers and we're in the early discussions.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the coal production potential expansion, I guess right now, what are your current production costs? And I guess going forward, as you expand the mine, are you envisioning kind of lower production costs because you have more scale? Or would you
componenttext: And then on the coal production potential expansion, I guess right now, what are your current production costs? And I guess going forward, as you expand the mine, are you envisioning kind of lower production costs because you have more scale? Or would you have kind of similar production costs?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not going to disclose our production costs and we have to sell the coal too. But we think the cost will be a little bit higher than what we currently bring out, but not necessarily in a material way. And in some of the places where we may take
componenttext: Well, we're not going to disclose our production costs and we have to sell the coal too. But we think the cost will be a little bit higher than what we currently bring out, but not necessarily in a material way. And in some of the places where we may take out the coal, the royalties maybe a little bit higher, given the tick up in prices. So we've had this project on the drawing board for little while, and we just waited until we were comfortable with coal prices and the outlook that we felt that it could be a good economic project.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, with all the asset sales that you guys have going on and the tax refund, it seems like you guys are going to build a decent cash pointed to the end of the year. I guess, what do you guys envision -- how do you guys envision spending tha
componenttext: And then, I guess, with all the asset sales that you guys have going on and the tax refund, it seems like you guys are going to build a decent cash pointed to the end of the year. I guess, what do you guys envision -- how do you guys envision spending that cash? Is that more to protect your balance sheet? Or is that to make kind of a strategic -- being in a position to do something towards the end of the year?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we have already built a pretty sizable cash balance already. And I think first and foremost, we're thinking about protecting the balance sheet and the capital program. And last year was a pretty painful year for the company and for the bala
componenttext: Well, I think, we have already built a pretty sizable cash balance already. And I think first and foremost, we're thinking about protecting the balance sheet and the capital program. And last year was a pretty painful year for the company and for the balance sheet. So I think first and foremost, it's to protect the balance sheet until we're comfortable that we're through the Refining down cycle. We're interested in growing parts of our business, the Retail business, the Logistics business. We've got a big project in coke to build and fund this year. So we see opportunities to put the capital to work. If we can find the right acquisitions or opportunities, we'll put the capital to work, at the same time protecting the balance sheet and making sure we get through the downturn.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: The $0.14 per share in income that you guys reported, that includes the discontinued operations at your Chemicals business. Is that right?
componenttext: The $0.14 per share in income that you guys reported, that includes the discontinued operations at your Chemicals business. Is that right?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is correct.
componenttext: That is correct.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Dietert with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Dietert with Simmons & Company.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mid-coal or mid-vol coal prices have improved meaningfully since you said prices last year, some of the recent transactions would suggest maybe a $2.50 per ton for met coal in Virginia. Could you talk about what kind of incremental earnings would be gener
componenttext: Mid-coal or mid-vol coal prices have improved meaningfully since you said prices last year, some of the recent transactions would suggest maybe a $2.50 per ton for met coal in Virginia. Could you talk about what kind of incremental earnings would be generated in 2011 relative to 2010, if that $2.50 per ton price were to hold for your Jewell mine and the associated Jewell coking facility?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I think, it's a little early for us to talk about that. I think we're working through exactly when, what rate the coal would come out of the mine in '11. And we haven't given guidance for '11. So I think it's a little early for us to really get into
componenttext: Jeff, I think, it's a little early for us to talk about that. I think we're working through exactly when, what rate the coal would come out of the mine in '11. And we haven't given guidance for '11. So I think it's a little early for us to really get into that.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I'm really just trying to get a sensitivity, so that I can order this, pricing and spot pricing and adjust as we go through time. So it's not really as much guidance as it is a way to compare 2010 to the current market in however it may evolve. And on
componenttext: And I'm really just trying to get a sensitivity, so that I can order this, pricing and spot pricing and adjust as we go through time. So it's not really as much guidance as it is a way to compare 2010 to the current market in however it may evolve. And one influence that might have on your coke profitability?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Clare. The sensitivity that we've generally given on coal prices is for every $25 per ton change in the price would affect our EBITDA, about $40 million, and our net income, $20 million to $25 million. That's probably all we could give you t
componenttext: Jeff, this is Clare. The sensitivity that we've generally given on coal prices is for every $25 per ton change in the price would affect our EBITDA, about $40 million, and our net income, $20 million to $25 million. That's probably all we could give you there. And you can try to gauge where the spot prices where when we contracted it as best you can.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On a separate issue, you talked about perhaps, monetizing $50 million in the retail, on the divestiture side. Are there other assets that you're considering for divestiture at this time?
componenttext: On a separate issue, you talked about perhaps, monetizing $50 million in the retail, on the divestiture side. Are there other assets that you're considering for divestiture at this time?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think we're always looking at our portfolio and thinking about our portfolio. But other than the retail assets that we've been explicit about, there's nothing more to really add today.
componenttext: No. I think we're always looking at our portfolio and thinking about our portfolio. But other than the retail assets that we've been explicit about, there's nothing more to really add today.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the corporate expenses, $23 million for the first quarter, a little bit higher than what I had expected. Could you talk about what influenced that? And give us some expectations for what a quarterly run rate would look like going forward.
componenttext: And on the corporate expenses, $23 million for the first quarter, a little bit higher than what I had expected. Could you talk about what influenced that? And give us some expectations for what a quarterly run rate would look like going forward.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say the quarterly run rate should trend lower than that. We had a few unusual items hit through Q1. But we can talk about it in detail later, nothing really notable to talk about.
componenttext: I would say the quarterly run rate should trend lower than that. We had a few unusual items hit through Q1. But we can talk about it in detail later, nothing really notable to talk about.

componenttext: Paul, the working capital change is as low in the web deck between SXL and Sunoco on Slide 11.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010

componenttext: Yes, I'd say, Mark -- one thing I'll tell you there is that, on the [indiscernible] (01:44:07) point, it is under -- the timing was kind of offset by some benefit. We add just ratability during the quarter. Usually, we're very ratable the way we purchase crude, just happen to be some benefit. So it wasn't as big as a hit you would like. But all totaled, outside of the turnaround, we had a significantly improved margin capture. And there were several aspects of that, that was the way we operated in our conversion units and yield gains. It was the one Lynn talked about earlier, in terms of actual realizations on our benchmark products, some help on our chemicals products out of the refinery. There is also a lift we got from after the Eagle Point closure in terms of our production mix.
