headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Sunoco, Inc.’s Q2 2010 earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on a listen-only mode until the question-and-answer session. Today’s call is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, you may disconnect at this time.I would
componenttext:
Welcome to Sunoco, Inc.’s Q2 2010 earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on a listen-only mode until the question-and-answer session. Today’s call is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, you may disconnect at this time.
I would now like to turn the call over to Lynn Elsenhans, Chairman and CEO. You may begin.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paula, and thank you and good evening to the audience. Welcome to Sunoco’s quarterly conference call, where we will be discussing the company’s second quarter earnings that we reported this afternoon.With me today are Brian MacDonald, our
componenttext:
Thank you, Paula, and thank you and good evening to the audience. Welcome to Sunoco’s quarterly conference call, where we will be discussing the company’s second quarter earnings that we reported this afternoon.
With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McGrory, the Manager of Investor Relations.
I’ll start by making a few introductory comments, and then Brian will address business results and comment on our overall financial position.
As part of today’s call, I would direct you to our Website, www.sunocoinc.com, where we have posted a number of presentation slides, which may provide a useful reference as we progress through our remarks. I’d also refer you to the Safe Harbor statement referenced in Slide #2 of the slide package, as we included it in this afternoon’s earning release. So now let’s begin.
Our second quarter results continue to show the benefits of the aggressive actions that we’ve taken to address the business issues within our control, and I’m pleased with the progress we’re making.
Our focus on margin capture and the decisive actions we’ve taken to reduce cost and improve reliability have returned our refining business to profitability for the first time since Q1 2009, and enabled our non-refining businesses to generate value and allowed us to build our cash position to $1.5 billion.
As you can see from Slide #3 and #4, we earned $158 million in net income excluding special items, or $1.31 per share. I’ll describe how we achieved that result in three parts.
First, we brought our refining business back to profitability by improving our margin capture and continuing to drive our cost. We also ran our refineries very well during the second quarter achieving 92% crude utilization rate. That’s the highest level since 2007.
The combination of better margin capture, plus cost reduction, plus safe and reliable operations along with some help from improved benchmarked margins enabled us to earn $86 million in refining alone.
The second part of this story involves our non-refining businesses which earned $166 million pretax. In addition to providing steady earnings for yet another quarter, they continued to grow and create value.
Sunoco Logistics recently announced the purchase of Texon, a butane blending business, which holds great promise for increasing earning, and represents real progress towards offering this state-of-the-art blending capabilities at terminals that differentiate Sunoco Logistics from competitors and help Sunoco to become the premier provider of transportation fuels in its markets.
In addition the recent announcement of Project Mariner, an effort to move ethane from Western Pennsylvania’s Marcellus Shale to Philadelphia for eventual transport to the Gulf Coast is another promising opportunity for Logistics.
The partnership also announced that it has exercised certain rights to increase its ownership interest in Mid-Valley Pipeline Company, West Texas Gulf Pipe Line Company and West Shore Pipe Line Company. These three pipeline transactions are expected to close within the next 30 days for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $100 million.
Sunoco Logistics isn’t the only area of the business where good things are happening. In June, we also started operations at our ethanol facility plant at Fulton New York as the largest ethanol plant in Northeast where much of our retail network is located.
The plant is uniquely situated to serve our ethanol requirements. At full production, it will provide up to 20% of our ethanol needs. As always, we continue to actively evaluate additional opportunities for growth within both the Retail and Logistics business.
The third and very important, development of our second quarter story is the strength of our balance sheet, which Brian will talk about in more detail later. We currently have about $1.5 billion in cash on hand and net debt of zero at the Sunoco parent level. We have come a long way and intend to continue protecting our balance sheet going forward.
As we get deeper into 2010, we expect market conditions for petroleum and chemical products to remain challenging. Demand is weak, product inventories across the industry are high, and margins are still pressured. However, we believe we are prepared.
We are working hard to further lower our break-even cost per barrel, so that we are profitable even in the worst of times. We are focusing on sustaining the progress we have made in margin capture and we are going to continue to run our refinery safely and reliable at the optimal capacity utilization.
This relentless focus on the fundamentals of our business will get us through the rest of the current down cycle in refining, but it’s delivering to shareholders on the promise of our brand-led future in the fuels business and to separate SunCoke Energy that we are really preparing for.
Our plan to separate SunCoke Energy from the rest of Sunoco in the first half of next year was conceived to unlock shareholder value and maximize the future success of both entities. The fuels and coke business are distinct businesses, with different models, different sets of customers and no significant integration or synergy.
With a dedicated management team and direct access to capital markets, SunCoke Energy will be better able to achieve the scale needed to pursue domestic and international growth opportunities.
Similarly Sunoco’s streamlined fuels business will be better positioned to become the premier provider of transportation fuels in its markets.
Before I turn the call over to Brian, I’ll say one more thing about the brand-led strategy that’s shaping Sunoco’s future. Whether we’re talking about petroleum-based fuels, pure bio fuels or some blend of the two, liquid fuels will be around for a long time.
We think there is good value to be created by being the supplier of choice for those fuels and having an iconic brand like the Sunoco Diamond that’s visible, durable and that customer’s trust is important. Sunoco wants to be positioned to provide the transportation fuels to the marketplace demand.
Now, let me turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported pretax income of $225 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders, which included $22 million pretax of net unfavorable special
componenttext:
Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported pretax income of $225 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders, which included $22 million pretax of net unfavorable special items.
The special items were primarily associated with pension settlement losses, employee terminations and related costs in connection with the business improvement initiative.
Our share of focus on achieving a competitive cost structure continues to yield results. Year-to-date cash operating expenses during the second quarter excluding fuel, utilities and discontinued operations were more than $100 million lower than the prior year’s expenses.
This expense measurement basis is used internally to track our progress and reducing our controllable expenses and demonstrates our efforts and success in driving our costs to a competitive level.
Before addressing some specifics regarding operating performance, let me say that we are very pleased with our performance during the quarter in which the market continued to present significant challenges. However, we cannot lose focus on the fundamentals as we believe that excess supply and low demand will continue to challenge our performance.
Regarding Q2 business unit results, I direct you to Slide #5, refining and supply had income of $138 million pretax or $86 million after-tax in the second quarter compared to the loss of $70 million pretax of $42 million after-tax in the first quarter. This represents the first quarter that we have generated profits for refining and supply since the first quarter of 2009.
While there were market factors that contributed to our strong performance, our actions to improve margin capture, our costs position and reliability were significant factors in achieving profitable results this quarter.
Operationally, we achieved a crude unit utilization rate of 92%, the highest system-wide utilization rated since 2007, and this quarter presented the first opportunity since the Eagle Point shutdown to optimize our Northeast as we underwent turnaround activity in the first quarter. Our system-wide conversion unit utilization rate was also strong at 90%.
With respect to Q2 marketing realization, I refer you to Slide #6 and #7 for more detail on our refining system crude costs and product differentials versus our benchmark. Our results reflect significant improvement in the second quarter versus recent quarters due to improved product realization as well as lower crude differentials.
As we indicated at last quarter’s conference call, we are capturing more of the benchmark margin that is available to us. While this was not very apparent in the first quarter results due to our planned turnaround activity as we increased utilization during the second quarter after our turnarounds, the progress we made is more visible in the results.
Well there are number of factors that affect our realization versus our benchmarks, we have aggressively taken actions to improve our margin realizations versus benchmark margins, and we are seeing some positive results.
In general, our benchmarks are up approximately $0.85 per barrel on average in the first quarter of 2010, while our realized margins were higher by about $3.25 per barrel.
As you can see on Slide #6, the improvement in our realized margins from the first quarter greatly exceeded the rise in the benchmark margin, and was about evenly spread between crude differentials and product differentials.
The improvement in crude differentials was largely driven by market conditions, falling crude prices specifically, while the product differential improvement can to a large degree be attributed to the success of our efforts to better match refining operations with market opportunities.
Our crude cost for the quarter averaged about $0.33 per barrel below our weighted benchmark, largely market driven as our crude prices are on a lag, and crude prices were falling during the quarter.
On the product side, our average differential was approximately $0.50 per barrel above our weighted benchmark. We are realizing better margins on our refinery production as we focus on taking advantage of the margin opportunities that exist and endeavor to ensure that our production is placed through the most profitable channels.
As the spread for higher value product such as diesel and premium gasoline widened, we shifted production to capture these opportunities. In the Northeast, we increased premium gasoline production 20% as compared to the second quarter of 2009, and across the entire system we increased ULSD production 33% from the second quarter of 2009.
In summary, our strong focus on operations and market opportunities led to strong performance in margin capture this quarter. Based on the progress, we have made we feel confident we can continue to deliver strong results within the controllable aspects of margin capture, but there can be market or operational factors which can affect our margin capture rate in any given reporting period.
Now let’s turn to the non-refining businesses which continue to contribute positive results. Our Retail Marketing, Logistics and Coke businesses earned $159 million pretax, $106 million after-tax, in aggregate during the quarter as detailed on Slide #8.
Retail Marketing earned $73 million pretax, $45 million after-tax in the second quarter of 2010. Retail gasoline margins were better than both the prior year and the first quarter of 2010 as they benefited from the decline in wholesale gasoline prices that occurred largely during May. Logistics earned $30 million pretax, $20 million after-tax. This business continues to be a source of steady earnings for Sunoco.
During the second quarter, we announced several new growth opportunities for the business and we continue to believe there are additional positive growth opportunities in the future.
Coke posted another solid contribution, earning $56 million pretax, $41 million after-tax in Q2 consistent with guidance, and as we noted last quarter, our Granite City coke facility encountered a slower startup than planned as we encountered some challenges within the operation.
We have made adjustments which should enable us to run the plant as designed at or near full charge rates for the remainder of the year. At this time, we maintain our full year guidance for SunCoke net income between $125 million to $140 million.
As Lynn previously indicated, with regard to the Coke business, construction continues as planned on our Middletown plant, and we look forward to our first coke production from that plant occurring in the second half of 2011.
Additionally, as announced last quarter, we have embarked on a project to increase our coal production at our SunCoke Jewell mining facility by approximately 0.5 million tons per year. We have initiated the project starting with the training of new miners. Lastly, our study to update the measure of our coal reserves at our Jewell mining facility is progressing.
Finally, let me take a few minutes to discuss our financial position at the end of June. In conjunction with that I direct you to Slides #9 and #10. From a cash flow perspective, our second quarter net cash flow before debt activity was approximately positive $580 million, largely driven by strong operating cash flow and a receipt of proceeds from the sale of the polypropylene business.
From a balance sheet perspective, at the Sunoco parent level, we ended the quarter with a net cash position of approximately $150 million, which included an improved cash position of $1.5 billion and $1.3 billion of debt.
On a consolidated basis, of the $1.1 billion net debt position approximately $1.2 billion of net debt was attributable to Sunoco Logistics Partners. We ended the quarter with a consolidated net debt-to-capital ratio of 25%. However, at the Sunoco level excluding Sunoco Logistics, we ended the quarter with a consolidated net debt-to-capital ratio of negative 6%.
From a liquidity standpoint at June 30, we had $1.5 billion of cash and approximately $1.8 billion of available committed borrowing capacity, which includes approximately $300 million available to Sunoco Logistics.
I also want to call your attention to a recent announcement that Sunoco was participating in the funding of Sunoco Logistics Partners acquisition of a butane blending business from Texon was $100 million loan to the partnership.
As reflected in our balance sheet, our financial position liquidity is very strong. As we look forward to the remainder of 2010, we will continue to take appropriate actions that will assist us in maintaining our financial flexibility to pursue attractive opportunities in our growth businesses.
A final balance sheet note related to inventory. At June 30, the current replacement costs of all the inventories valued at LIFO exceeds their carrying value by $2.6 billion.
I’ll take a few minutes to address our plans to separate SunCoke. As Lynn indicated earlier, this plan separation is part of a strategy to unlock shareholder value and maximize the future success of both entities. We have no changes to the plans that we discussed at our Analyst Meeting, approximately a month ago.
We still plan to affect the separation in the first half of 2011 and are in the process of evaluating appropriate form of separation in the capital structures that will exist for both entities. We will share more information when we are able to within the confines of the process.
So, in closing to build a better Sunoco and to deliver value to shareholders, we remain focused on the fundamentals, running our refineries safely and reliably at optimal capacity utilization, lowering our break-even cost per barrel, and furthering the progress we have made in capturing available margin. This focus in continued investment in our brand and ability to serve customers will help us achieve our aspiration of becoming the preferred provider of transportation fuels in our markets.
With that, I’ll ask the operator to open up the lines for your questions.

componenttext: No. We don’t break it out. I would say I gave you the contango benefit. That’s the only contango benefit. componenttext: Maybe, Brian, when you’re looking at the cost structure of the company, I think, Lynn has done a lot of trying to reduce it, and you continue to talk about it. Over the next six to nine months, what is the current run rate that we should assume, are we going to see any significant further improvement on the cost structure, or that your use more or less by reaching a status quo at this point?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are a couple of areas that we are pursuing. I’d say, in general, we have a continuous pursuit to try to improve the cost structure of the business, but two that are in line of sight, is not all of the benefits the kinds of things we did in the Nor
componenttext:
There are a couple of areas that we are pursuing. I’d say, in general, we have a continuous pursuit to try to improve the cost structure of the business, but two that are in line of sight, is not all of the benefits the kinds of things we did in the Northeast refining system have shown up in Toledo yet.
So we should see a little bit more there and showing up more in the cost of goods and the cost of capital projects than operating expense, we’d also expect to see similar procurement benefits showing through a little bit on the OpEx side to be sure, but probably most of it in cost to goods and so those are the two biggest buckets that I think you’ll see.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: A final one, in terms of the capture way in the crude, I think Clare has said that it’s about $0.55 is the crude slate, five-day lag and that you also have maybe $0.15 for the contango, but comparing to historically, it seems like that you are still doi
componenttext: A final one, in terms of the capture way in the crude, I think Clare has said that it’s about $0.55 is the crude slate, five-day lag and that you also have maybe $0.15 for the contango, but comparing to historically, it seems like that you are still doing better than what historic is. Is that structurally that we should assume that type of better crude purchases going to maintain or there’s other item that we should be considering? And same in the product side that the stronger realization comparing to your benchmark, how much of them is really sustainable and what maybe the one-off factor that we need to take into consideration?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first part of your question, Paul that had to do with systemically capturing the crude differential. I wouldn’t say it’s systemic as much as it is market opportunity, and one, being able to take advantage of that opportunity through having good re
componenttext:
The first part of your question, Paul that had to do with systemically capturing the crude differential. I wouldn’t say it’s systemic as much as it is market opportunity, and one, being able to take advantage of that opportunity through having good reliable operation, so that part of it you could now talk about as being systemically different in terms of we’re very, very focused on that.
But then depending on what the market suggests would be the most optimum slate to run. In some of those cases, the quality differentials in the market are going to be better, in some cases they are not going to be as good. So, I wouldn’t say that systemic as much as it is quality differentials on some of the crudes like a Doba or Syncrude change over time and they were relatively better this past quarter.
The other part of your question on the product differential; I’d tell you is much the same kind of answer that good product reliability is the key, but I would point out that on the ability to produce ultra low sulfur diesel we do have a structural change, and we were able to produce a record amount because of the Philadelphia hydrocracker project that came on in the fourth quarter of ‘09 that now that we saw some good margin in ULSD we were able to take advantage of that because of the project that had come on. And then additionally just post the Toledo hydrocracker turnaround and that hydrocracker running very well, the combination of the two led to a record on the diesel production.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, the other part I’d like to add to that discussion, I think, if you go back a couple quarters, we clearly said we weren’t very satisfied with our margin capture rate and we’re taking a number of actions to try to improve the capture rate. Unfor
componenttext:
Paul, the other part I’d like to add to that discussion, I think, if you go back a couple quarters, we clearly said we weren’t very satisfied with our margin capture rate and we’re taking a number of actions to try to improve the capture rate. Unfortunately in Q1 because of some of the timing of our turnarounds we didn’t necessarily see a lot of that benefit, but we’re clearly seeing some of the benefit in Q2.
As I think we’ve mentioned before, we’ve made this one of our executive compensation metrics for the company, for the entire company for 2010. So the organization is pretty focused on improving our margin capture. That all said, there will be some quarters which are better than others in terms of what’s going on in the market and what are the particular opportunities, but I think the takeaway should be that we weren’t very satisfied with how this progressed last year and we’ve made it a pretty big area of focus, and we hope that we will continue to run at a rate better than we have over the recent past.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On your analyst presentation in mid-June, you presented a slide on margin capture that showed the second quarter-to-date capture rate at about 90% of an indicator margin of 6.50 and the quarter ended with the indicator margin at about 6.50 as well, and ye
componenttext: On your analyst presentation in mid-June, you presented a slide on margin capture that showed the second quarter-to-date capture rate at about 90% of an indicator margin of 6.50 and the quarter ended with the indicator margin at about 6.50 as well, and yet your margin capture rate was 113%. So that went from roughly $5.85 a barrel to $7.34 a barrel. That’s about $0.55 a share in earnings, in difference; it explains the difference between the consensus estimate and what you actually reported. Can you explain the difference between your forecast on 6.15, and where you ended up for the quarter?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, two things, Jeff. I think in June we said we expected our margin capture rate to be at least 90% and that was based upon the best available data we had at that time.
componenttext: Yes, I think, two things, Jeff. I think in June we said we expected our margin capture rate to be at least 90% and that was based upon the best available data we had at that time.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s a huge variance with only 15 days left in the month. How do you explain such a large variance?
componenttext: That’s a huge variance with only 15 days left in the month. How do you explain such a large variance?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what I said is that was in the middle of June, and we had only partial quarterly information, not a full month of May’s data, and we were careful to say that the result would be at least 90%, because June could have been lower than the pri
componenttext: Well, I think what I said is that was in the middle of June, and we had only partial quarterly information, not a full month of May’s data, and we were careful to say that the result would be at least 90%, because June could have been lower than the prior two months, and so that was our guidance around that at that time.

componenttext: My second question is on cost, and I know you guys are very focused on the cost side. I mean can you provide any guidance on corporate? I know it’s been trending lower with $20 million this quarter in headquarter relocation. I meant what should we think about as a run rate there? And then additionally, I know you’d mentioned a goal of achieving a breakeven at a $5 margin. I mean is that moving lower or is there potentially a lower target there?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say on the cost side, Evan I mean we continue to work that pretty hard. We’ve gotten pretty good results to-date. We are also trying to run the unit a little bit higher to which has the potential to add in a little bit of costs as well, bu
componenttext:
Well, I would say on the cost side, Evan I mean we continue to work that pretty hard. We’ve gotten pretty good results to-date. We are also trying to run the unit a little bit higher to which has the potential to add in a little bit of costs as well, but also increasing the volume when the margins are where they are.
I’m going to ask Clare to just comment on the corporate piece. There are a couple of things going on in the corporate piece. I mean last year, there was no bonus at the company last year, and so this year we are truing for a bonus. So that’s a little bit of delta year-over-year and one factor that’s going through there, but I will turn it over to Clare.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that’s the probably the biggest factor, especially year-over-year and even 2Q versus 1Q. If you remember, 1Q had some unusual one-time tax hit adjustments in there. So, we are still down from 1Q, but we had some higher accruals relative to the comp
componenttext: Yes, that’s the probably the biggest factor, especially year-over-year and even 2Q versus 1Q. If you remember, 1Q had some unusual one-time tax hit adjustments in there. So, we are still down from 1Q, but we had some higher accruals relative to the company’s performance, and I’d say a few other one-time type items, legal and contractor type items.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan as you would imagine, we are starting to spend some money on coke separations and putting some capabilities in there that we may need if the company becomes a publicly-traded company. We have some capability gaps that we need to start to build o
componenttext:
Yes, Evan as you would imagine, we are starting to spend some money on coke separations and putting some capabilities in there that we may need if the company becomes a publicly-traded company. We have some capability gaps that we need to start to build out. We have some costs incurred as we evaluate these options.
You’ll note in our press release that we announced that we signed an outsourcing deal with IBM in Q2 for a large percentage of the finance and IT organizations. We had some costs in Q2 to facilitate that contract signing and get that process going. So we’re taking out cost but we’re also spending money on a few things that are going to either take out more cost in the future or help facilitate the value creation we expect with the SunCoke separation.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Gilman. Your line is now open.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

componenttext: It’s a one month forward basis. So that’s where the contango benefit comes in, when WTI is in a contango position.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, one for Brian. Brian, it seems to me that this loan that you discussed to fund SXL’s pipeline acquisitions is just another indication of the potential for financial inefficiency of the SXL structure as it exists currently. Do you agree with
componenttext: And finally, one for Brian. Brian, it seems to me that this loan that you discussed to fund SXL’s pipeline acquisitions is just another indication of the potential for financial inefficiency of the SXL structure as it exists currently. Do you agree with that?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

componenttext: No. I’m kind of curious, what your logic is.

componenttext: Well, the logic is that the heavily leveraged position of SXL burdens the consolidated financial position of Sunoco.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would tell you that they’re both separately rated entities and they both have their own leverage characteristic. They both have their separate sources of capital; and at the end of the day, we’re the largest LP unit holder in Sunoco Logistics,
componenttext: Well, I would tell you that they’re both separately rated entities and they both have their own leverage characteristic. They both have their separate sources of capital; and at the end of the day, we’re the largest LP unit holder in Sunoco Logistics, and we’re the general partner with a very good incentive distribution right structure. So, we’re very incented to facilitate the growth of the company as well as efficient financing of the company.

componenttext: We have separate financing facilities for both entities and they have separate covenants, separate pricing structures, and obviously, Sunoco is the general partner of Sunoco Logistics. So, that plays into the considerations that external parties would look at, but they have at the end of the day separate and distinct business profiles and separate and distinct balance sheet characteristics and sources of funding and ratios.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

componenttext: So one, just a point of clarity on the Retail business. During the analyst conference, I got the impression, the strategy was to increase the slice of existing market share on the East Coast and the way the press release is worded, I kind of get the impression that you are looking to grow geographically via footprint? I’m just trying to understand, which one is correct?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s kind of both. I think that given our strength in the Northeast market, it’s a real natural for us to even build upon that strength, but we would also consider expanding a little bit in the footprints that have good logistic capability for us and
componenttext: It’s kind of both. I think that given our strength in the Northeast market, it’s a real natural for us to even build upon that strength, but we would also consider expanding a little bit in the footprints that have good logistic capability for us and ones in which our Retail business would be on either a level playing field or where we might have some advantage from a logistic standpoint. So, we would be open to both, but I think most likely because of the strength that we already have in the Northeast and the near mid-continent; you would see probably more opportunity for us there first.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the emphasis is on the Northeast. And then secondly, I don’t know if this is a question for Brian, but with the net debt-to-cap of negative 6%, I know we are not out of the woods by any means from the economy, but do you contemplate some kind of acqu
componenttext: So the emphasis is on the Northeast. And then secondly, I don’t know if this is a question for Brian, but with the net debt-to-cap of negative 6%, I know we are not out of the woods by any means from the economy, but do you contemplate some kind of acquisition or growth opportunities or maybe even share repurchases or dividend increases, I’m just wondering what the capital structure is going to look like going forward?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re looking at acquisitions now, and if we find something that makes economic and strategic sense, we would execute against it. We also want to continue to support Sunoco Logistics and the growth opportunities there. So we’ve got the cash ready to d
componenttext: We’re looking at acquisitions now, and if we find something that makes economic and strategic sense, we would execute against it. We also want to continue to support Sunoco Logistics and the growth opportunities there. So we’ve got the cash ready to do that. Obviously, we’re watching the refining down cycle and how that evolves, and then as we get through that and get through the coke separation, then we’ll have a more holistic view of the balance sheet and the capital structures for both Sunoco and the coke business.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Blake, I would just add that on the acquisition side, we don’t have anything specific to talk about today, but I’d like to just reiterate that we’re really only interested in potential acquisitions in our high-return businesses of SXL, Retail a
componenttext: Yes. Blake, I would just add that on the acquisition side, we don’t have anything specific to talk about today, but I’d like to just reiterate that we’re really only interested in potential acquisitions in our high-return businesses of SXL, Retail and Coke. We’re not looking to expand the refining business.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

componenttext: Not on the refining side, but continue to have a lot of interest on the Logistics, Retail, and Coke side. You have noticed some of the recent announcements for Logistics, we’re able to take advantage of where majors have decided that they would like to exit their interest, and that becomes a good opportunity for us.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to get your thoughts on the gasoline import market in the Northeast. It seems like we have seen a noticeable ramp up in imports from India over the last six to 12 months presumably from Jamnagar. I know, Lynn, you’ve said in the past that from a
componenttext: I want to get your thoughts on the gasoline import market in the Northeast. It seems like we have seen a noticeable ramp up in imports from India over the last six to 12 months presumably from Jamnagar. I know, Lynn, you’ve said in the past that from a supply standpoint you are about a third, a third, a third as far as regional production, Gulf Coast deliveries and imports. How do you see the long term dynamics playing out on the imports with essentially a large new source on top of what’s coming from Europe, Canada, and the Caribbean?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the way I see that is that the higher cost barrels will come out and to make room for that demand has to grow. I don’t the overall demand growth being bullish. So, what I would see happen over a period of time is that some of the smaller, less, com
componenttext: Yes, the way I see that is that the higher cost barrels will come out and to make room for that demand has to grow. I don’t the overall demand growth being bullish. So, what I would see happen over a period of time is that some of the smaller, less, complex refineries whether they be in Northern Europe or the United States will have to come down because it would appear that the product coming in from Jamnagar is able to even with the transportation come in and compete.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there’s certainly hasn’t been anything stopping them from the looks of it here. So you believe that the markets then did fairly efficient than in the Northeast, is that what you’re saying?
componenttext: Yes, there’s certainly hasn’t been anything stopping them from the looks of it here. So you believe that the markets then did fairly efficient than in the Northeast, is that what you’re saying?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could help me on a couple things. I guess first, if I’m looking at your product yield, it’s changed dramatically this quarter versus the first quarter, and last year, I think you produced about 80,000 barrels a day of more gasol
componenttext: I was wondering if you could help me on a couple things. I guess first, if I’m looking at your product yield, it’s changed dramatically this quarter versus the first quarter, and last year, I think you produced about 80,000 barrels a day of more gasoline and distillate over the first quarter and your secondary products kind of remained relatively flat. So I think, you talked about the Philly hydrocracker and I think some of the investments you’ve made in Toledo. I guess is this the new product yield going forward? Can we rely on this product yield for the rest of this year and next year?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of points there. One of the other structural differences for the yield is the fact that Eagle Point is no longer in the production mix, and you will have seen in the second quarter quarter-to-quarter from last year, a 20% increase in premium gasoli
componenttext:
Couple of points there. One of the other structural differences for the yield is the fact that Eagle Point is no longer in the production mix, and you will have seen in the second quarter quarter-to-quarter from last year, a 20% increase in premium gasoline make and relative to the first quarter of this year, a 60% increase. And I wouldn’t say that something like that is necessarily going to be structural. That will depend on market dynamics, but if the market is there then our job would be to see that opportunity and leverage up those premium barrels.
And then on the diesel side I would say, yes. We’ve made some changes that would structurally allow us to make a higher percentage of on-road diesel out of the total distillate pool. But again, it wouldn’t make sense to do that unless the margins for diesel were there relative to gasoline, and so again, based on the market, we’ll try to optimize the mix of gasoline and diesel that we make within the envelope of the capability of the equipment.

componenttext: I don’t think significantly on that. I guess what I’d say is that, if you look at the second quarter of last year versus the second quarter of this year, we did have some additional lift from the chemical margins relative to the crack, but not so much of a difference between the first quarter of this year and the second quarter of this year.

componenttext: And then I guess you’re talking about acquisition, you said you would more interested in looking at pipelines in logistics assets for Sunoco Logistics. headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Sunoco Inc.'s Q3 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Lynn Elsenhans, Chairman and CEO. You may begin.
componenttext: Welcome to Sunoco Inc.'s Q3 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Lynn Elsenhans, Chairman and CEO. You may begin.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good evening. Welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call where we will discuss the company's third quarter earnings that we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McGrory, Manag
componenttext:
Thank you, and good evening. Welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call where we will discuss the company's third quarter earnings that we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McGrory, Manager of Investor Relations. I'll start by making a few introductory comments, and then Brian will address business results and comment on the overall financial position. 
As part of today's call, I'd like to direct you to our website, www.sunocoinc.com, where we have posted a number of presentation slides, which may provide a useful reference as we progress through our remarks. I would also refer you to the Safe Harbor statement referenced in Slide 2 at the Slide package and is included in the afternoon's earnings release. 
Now let's begin. In the third quarter, we faced a challenging market environment, particularly in the Northeast. Excess supply pressures margins, which deteriorated from second quarter levels. In addition, rising crude costs at the end of the quarter hurt our result. However, our year-over-year third quarter results which have comparable market conditions in both periods improved significantly, thanks to the actions that we have taken to address the business which is in our control. 
As you can see from Slide 3 and 4, we earned $27 million in net income, excluding special items or $0.22 per share. There are three aspects of our performance this quarter that I would like to review. First, I will cover the Fuels business, particularly in Retail and Logistics, which together earned $110 million in pretax income during the quarter. Either strong business that are generating significant value today, and which present promising opportunities for continued growth. 
During the third quarter, Sunoco Logistics Partners LT closed on the purchase of additional ownership interest in three pipeline joint ventures. These moves added immediate value to both Sunoco and Sunoco Logistics. And we continue to evaluate other opportunities for growth in both these businesses. 
Continuing with the Fuels business, Refining and Supply posted a loss of $70 million pretax in the quarter. We face deterioration in market margins, which at least temporarily overshadowed our ongoing work on the controllable areas of our business. Market conditions in the third quarter demonstrated that we continue to face challenges in the business segment. However, I call your attention to the fact that in Refining and Supply, we are near break even on a year-to-date basis compared to last year, that's an improvement of approximately $205 million pretax. 
Now we're certainly not satisfied with break-even performance, but that kind of improvement reflects the progress we've made. We expect that the fourth quarter will be at least as challenging as the first three quarters of 2010. And accordingly, we've maintained focus on the fundamentals of safety and reliability, margin capture and maintaining a competitive cost structure. 
The second aspect of our performance that I'll cover is the Coke business , which had a strong quarter and earned $44 million of pretax income. We benefited from strong operations in a positive market condition. Coke continued success set the stage for promising future as a stand-alone business. In addition, we continue to see strong growth opportunities in Coke both in the U.S. and internationally over the next 10 or more years. 
Finally, the third element of the quarter that I will touch on is the strength of our balance sheet, which Brian will talk about in more detail later. Our cash balance continues to be healthy and our debt position is strong at approximately $175 million, excluding Sunoco Logistics. 
At the end of the third quarter, our net debt to capital ratio for Sunoco, excluding SXL, was 6% as compared to 39% at the same time last year. Our improvement over time is evident and we will continue protecting our balance sheet going forward. 
At the third quarter, market environment has demonstrated, we expect market conditions for petroleum and chemical products to remain challenging, demand is weak, product inventories across the industry are high and margins are still under pressure. We're working hard to further lower our breakeven cost per barrel so that we're able to generate cash in difficult times. We're focused on sustaining the progress we've made in margin capture, and we're going to continue to run our refineries safely and reliably at optimal capacity utilization. 
Focus on the fundamentals of our business will get us through the rest of the current downcycle and refining and it's delivering to shareholders on the promise of our brands and Logistics led future in the Fuels business and a separate Coke company, SunCoke Energy that we're preparing for. Let me now turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported pretax income of $95 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in Q3, which included $62 million of pretax net favorable speci
componenttext:
Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported pretax income of $95 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in Q3, which included $62 million of pretax net favorable special items. The special items were primarily associated with pension settlement losses, employee terminations and related costs in connection with the business improvement initiative, a gain on an MTBE insurance settlement and a non-cash gain related to an acquisition accounting at Sunoco Logistics. 
While we've delivered another strong quarter in our Retail Logistics and Coke businesses, we continue to face challenging market conditions in our Refining and Supply business. As seen on Slide 4, Refining and Supply recorded a pretax loss of $70 million as excess supply and continued low demand pressured market cracks further downward from the prior quarter. While we are certainly not satisfied in posting a loss in our Refining and Supply business, the business did improve as pretax income by $112 million as compared to the same quarter of last year when market conditions were fairly similar to this quarter. We feel confident that this significant improvement is, to a large degree, the result of actions we have taken including the closure of the Eagle Point refinery, the focus on reliability and optimization of our plants, re-engineering our market strategy, and last but not the least, our initiatives around cost structure.  Our sharp focus on achieving a competitive cost structure continues to yield results. 
Year-to-date cash operating expenses to the third quarter, excluding fuel, utilities and discontinued operations, were approximately $170 million lower than the prior years. Excluding the Coke business where we're adding costs as we grow and prepare for separation, the improvement versus prior year is approximately $200 million. This expense measure of cash operating expenses x fuel and utilities is used internally to track our products and reducing our controllable expenses, and is also part of our executive compensation targets and demonstrates our efforts and success in driving our costs to a competitive level. 
A year ago, when we announced our decision to close the Eagle Point refinery, we communicated our goal to achieve breakeven cash flow in our Refining and Supply business even within the tough market environment like we were experiencing at the time. As a result of the actions we have taken, on a year-to-date basis, we are free cash flow breakeven in our Refining and Supply business, excluding working capital changes. And in the fourth quarter of 2010, we expect to generate significant cash through the permanent liquidation of inventories, largely related to the closure of the Eagle Point refinery. So we plan to achieve positive cash flow in Refining and Supply in 2010, pouring a substantial decline in the market during the fourth quarter. This reflects a significant improvement in the Refining and Supply business as compared to last year when the business experienced a significant cash burn. So while we continue to be pleased with our progress in many of the controllable aspects of our operations, it is evident that the market will continue to present significant challenges and we maintain focus on the fundamentals to ensure we are competitive with our assets. 
Regarding our Q3 business unit results, I direct you to Slides 4 through 8. Specifically, Retail Marketing earned $68 million pretax in the third quarter of 2010, while retail gasoline margins were below the strong periods of second quarter and the prior year, they were still relatively strong despite the overall rise in wholesale gasoline prices during the period, which typically pressures retail margins. 
As compared to the same quarter of the prior year, gasoline and diesel volumes were up about 1% and 8%, respectively on an open both years basis. Additionally, we continue to evaluate acquisition opportunities, and we have been successful at growing our Distributor business incrementally adding net 86 tight store network during the third quarter. At the end of the third quarter, 4,829 total sites carried the Sunoco flag, and we want to grow that further. 
Logistics are in $42 million pretax as Sunoco Logistics Partners continues to be a reliable and ratable source of earnings for Sunoco. The throughput in term lien business has proven to be a ratable and growing business and is supplement to by crude oil market opportunities when contango market structures exist. 
During the third quarter, we closed on the purchase of three pipeline interest that are immediately accretive to earnings, and we continue to believe there are additional positive growth opportunities in the future. Sunoco Logistics Partners is projecting over $435 million in total capital expenditures in 2010, including both organic and acquisition projects. 
As we mentioned in our Q2 earnings calls, Sunoco has facilitated some of this growth via $100 million intercompany loan to Sunoco Logistics that occurred in Q3 and was one of the primary reasons that our cash balance is lower in Q3 versus Q2. 
Coke posted another solid contribution earning $44 million pretax in Q3. During the third quarter, we operate it well in all of our facilities, including our Granite City facility, which started operations late last year. We also benefited during this period from spot sales of Coke production from the 2009 downturn. At this time, we maintained our full year guidance for SunCoke net income at $125 million to $140 million in net income as we expect expenses to be higher from investments and growth in separation planning and no spot Coke sales in Q4. 
As shown on Slide 6, Refining and Supply had a loss of $70 million pretax in the third quarter 2010 compared to a loss of $182 million pretax in the same quarter of 2009. If you recall, last quarter was the first quarter that we generated profits for Refining and Supply since the first quarter of 2009. In our last quarterly call, we said there were market factors that contributed to our strong performance, our actions to improve margin capture, cost position and reliability were significant factors in achieving profitable results. 
In the third quarter, market conditions deteriorated particularly in the Northeast. For the aspects of our business that are under our control, we largely performed well, although we did experience some operational issues that will impact our performance in the fourth quarter. Operationally, we achieved a crude unit utilization rate of 94%, higher than last quarter and in line with our plan. However, our systemwide Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel production was down by approximately 4,000 barrels per day from the second quarter due to some operational issues. 
With respect to our Q3 margin realizations, I refer you to Slides 7 and 8 for more detail on the refining system crude costs and product differentials versus our benchmark. Our third quarter results reflect significant improvement versus the same quarter of the prior year. As we indicated at last quarter's conference call, we are capturing more of the benchmark margin that is available to us and this is evident again this quarter in the year-over-year improvement. While there are number of factors that affect our realizations versus our benchmarks, which are market related, we have taken actions on identified opportunities to improve our margin realizations versus benchmark margins, and we continue to see the benefits from these actions. 
As you can see on Slide 7, our refining-wide, Refining and Supply benchmark averaged $4.87 per barrel for the third quarter, only about $0.30 better than the same quarter of last year. However, our margin capture of 80% was significantly improved from Q3 '09 margin capture of 60%. And excluding the negative impact of crude timing, margin capture for the third quarter of 2010 was 90%. The significant improvement in margin capture versus last year can be attributed to improve reliability and the successful strategy matching the operations to market opportunities. The improved reliability in utilization is both in the Northeast and Toledo.  Overall, as compared to last year, we benefited from higher overall distillates and ULSD production as a percent of total production. 
In Q3 2010, 37% of our net production was distillates versus 33% in Q3 '09 with the offset and less of achieved for residual field. Our actions has supported this improvement include the closure of Eagle Point, adjustments in our crudes play and the operation of the new hydrocracker unit in Philadelphia. Within the distillate pool, we are operating more of the distillate ULSD versus last year and Northeast ULSD differentials have wind by more than $0.02 a gallon quarter-over-quarter. 
Using second quarter 2010 as a basis, benchmark margins and margin capture declined in the third quarter and shows us that even with the improvement from last year, we have more work to do on cost reduction and margin capture. Benchmark margins fell by $1.65 per barrel on average as neither gasoline prices nor distillate prices kept up with a rising crude cost. Realized margins were $3.88 per barrel, resulting in a margin capture of 80% versus 113% in the second quarter. The biggest driver in this decline in margin capture from the second quarter to the third quarter was within crude differentials, and largely due to market conditions, namely rising crude prices. 
Our crude cost for the quarter averaged about $0.92 per barrel above our weighted benchmark and approximately $0.50 of the $0.92 relates to the timing of our crude prices. This factor is a complete reversal from the prior quarter when crude prices were falling and timing actually provided a benefit to our realized margins. As a reminder, our crude purchases in the Northeast priced in the lag and the price of crude rose during the quarter and in particular during the latter period of pricing in the first five days of October. 
Excluding the impact of crude timing in either quarter, margin capture dropped from approximately 104% in Q2 to approximately 90% in Q3. On the product side, our average differential was approximately $0.07 per barrel below our weighted benchmark. While this bid drop off from a very strong Q2 performance, as you compare it to the last several periods, you will see that it was dramatically improved and reflects our focus on improving our reliability and placing our production through the most profitable channels. 
Relative to Q2, the product realizations were challenged by a following gasoline market. In the third quarter, the gasoline crack in the Northeast declined by almost $4 per barrel from the prior quarter. Additionally, we did not get the same lift in realized margins and margin capture from value-added products as premium and our above differentials in conventional gasoline also narrowed substantially. 
In the period of rising absolute prices, petrochemical and other non-crack product prices were not able to keep pace with the rising and volatile benchmark prices. Lastly and the fact that it was most within our control, the ULSD production, the Northeast complex dropped from the second quarter levels due to operational issues. In summary, we still feel confident that we're executing on many of the factors within our control, both operational and how we are approaching the market. As we noted last quarter, there can be market factors which affect our margin capture rate in any given reporting period as with the case this quarter. We have remain focused on the fundamentals and those elements within our control. To drive Sunoco performance in whatever environment exists. 
So in the fourth quarter, we will be performing maintenance in our Northeast system. Additionally our crude throughput and Toledo will be negatively impacted by pipeline allocations that resulted from the Enbridge line interruptions. Accordingly, we expect challenge Refining and Supply results in Q4, given the resulting low-utilization level and weak market conditions. 
Finally, let me take a few minutes to discuss our fiscal position at the end of the quarter. In conjunction with that, I direct you to Slides 9 and 10. From a funds low perspective, our third quarter net cash flow before debt activity at Sunoco, excluding Sunoco Logistics, was the use of approximately $327 million. We ended the quarter with a net debt position of approximately $175 million, excluding Sunoco Logistics. The sequential cash decline in the quarter was driven by working capital movements and the loan of $100 million by Sunoco to Sunoco Logistics to help support its acquisition of Texon, a Butane Blending business. We ended the quarter with a net debt of capital ratio of 6% at the Sunoco level, excluding Sunoco Logistics. 
At September 30, we had $1.1 billion of cash and approximately $1.5 billion of available committed borrowing capacity at Sunoco, excluding Sunoco Logistics. As reflected in our balance sheet, our financial position and liquidity continues to be very strong. Additionally, in the fourth quarter of 2010, we do plan to generate cash flow through the permanent liquidation of the inventory that's primarily to Eagle Point closure. As we look forward to the remaining months of 2010 and into 2011, we will continue to take appropriate actions that will assist us in maintaining our financial flexibility to pursue attractive opportunities in our growth businesses, as well as ride out the refining downturn. 
As an update to our capital plans for 2010, our latest planned capital spending for Refining and Supply in 2010 is approximately $225 million, about $50 million less than we last guided in June. This reduction has been achieved primarily due to cost efficiencies in projects as well as some deferred projects which have no impact on safe and reliable operations. There are no other changes to our 2010 capital guidance at this point in time. 
For 2011, our planned capital spending for Refining and Supply is between $225 million and $250 million in line with current year spend and below DD&A. 
A final balance sheet note related to inventory. At September 30, the current replacement cost of all inventories valued at LIFO exceeds their carrying value by $2.8 billion. I'll take a few minutes to Provide an update on our plans to separate SunCoke. As we have said, this planned separation is part of a strategy to unlock shareholder value and maximize the future success of both Sunoco and SunCoke. We still plan to affect the separation in the first half of 2011 and are in the process of evaluating the appropriate form of separation. 
During the third quarter, we announced the hiring of Fritz Henderson to lead the separated SunCoke business. We also announced that the business will relocate after the separation to a city more internationally accessible with the preferred location being Chicago. Most recently in late October, we filed our IRS private letter ruling requesting the tax re-separation. We continue to work through the other aspects of the separation process, including any filings that would be necessary if SunCoke were to be a separate public company. As you can see we are moving steadily down the path to separation in the first half of 2011, and we will share more information when we are able to within the confines of the process. 
So in closing, to build a better Sunoco and to deliver value to shareholders, we remain focused on the fundamentals: Running our refineries safely and reliably in optimal capacity; lowering our breakeven cost per barrel; and furthering the progress we have made in capturing available margins. This focus and continued investment in our brand and ability to serve customers will help us achieve our aspiration of becoming the preferred provider of transportation fuels in our markets. 
With that, I'll ask the operator to open the lines for any questions you may have.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are you able to quantify the potential value of the inventory that you're trying to liquidate? And my follow-up is a capital question. So it looks like CapEx has come down obviously into the Refining business below depreciation levels. What does that mean
componenttext: Are you able to quantify the potential value of the inventory that you're trying to liquidate? And my follow-up is a capital question. So it looks like CapEx has come down obviously into the Refining business below depreciation levels. What does that mean in terms of the carrying value, of the carrying book value half of the refining system? Is that a sustainable situation? And I guess if you could quantify also any downtimes/maintenance plans that you have both in the fourth quarter and through the next year, that would be great.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, Doug. I'll try to punch through these. So when we announced the closure of Eagle Point, we said that we would take out roughly between $250 million and $300 million of inventory related to that. We took about half of that out in the fourth quarter o
componenttext: Okay, Doug. I'll try to punch through these. So when we announced the closure of Eagle Point, we said that we would take out roughly between $250 million and $300 million of inventory related to that. We took about half of that out in the fourth quarter of last year. And so as we get to the fourth quarter, we become more in the range of the second half of that and they move up and down a little bit based upon market conditions and things that are going on in the operations, but that's kind of broadly the magnitude of the second half of that inventory reduction, which we said, would be permanent. The second question with regard to CapEx, and the CapEx being in refining below the DD&A, at this time, we're only giving guidance for 2011 which is obviously below DD&A. And what I would say is that over the last few years, Sunoco had invested a lot of capital into the refining assets for various consent decree and other projects. So you need to put the current capital spend against DD&A in the context of the kind of projects in particular consent decree projects that were done for most of the recent past.

componenttext: Mark, we have said all along that we think it's good to have growth in all the classes of trade in retail and that it helps -- even if it's a distributor, they have a contract with us, it provides more ratable off take, more plannable off take for us and as a higher net back channel than if we just put it into the unbranded business. headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, I appreciate the detailed comments on the margin capture in your opening remarks, my question is regarding Coke. As I look at prices that were available in the marketplace this time last year versus this year, there's a $75 to $100 a ton improvemen
componenttext: Brian, I appreciate the detailed comments on the margin capture in your opening remarks, my question is regarding Coke. As I look at prices that were available in the marketplace this time last year versus this year, there's a $75 to $100 a ton improvement in met coal pricing just using your metrics on a $25 a ton converts to about $20 million a year net income. And then you add in a partial year of Middletown, it seems 2011 Coke net income should comfortably be over $200 million. Am I doing my math right?

componenttext: I would say, Jeff, you're doing your math right. And we're obviously, we've yet to lock in our contract prices for 2011, and we also have some tax credit that are factored in net income. At this point, we do see very ratable tax credits in 2011 versus 2010.
