headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Sunoco, Inc.’s Q3 2010 earnings conference call. All lines have been placed in a listen-only mode until the question-and-answer session. Today’s call is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, you may disconnect at this time.I would
componenttext:
Welcome to Sunoco, Inc.’s Q3 2010 earnings conference call. All lines have been placed in a listen-only mode until the question-and-answer session. Today’s call is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, you may disconnect at this time.
I would now like to turn the call over to Lynn Elsenhans, Chairman and CEO. You may begin.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good evening. Welcome to Sunoco’s quarterly conference call where we will discuss the company’s third quarter earnings that were reported this afternoon.With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer and Clare McGrory,
componenttext:
Thank you, and good evening. Welcome to Sunoco’s quarterly conference call where we will discuss the company’s third quarter earnings that were reported this afternoon.
With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer and Clare McGrory, Manager of Investor Relations.
I’ll start by making a few introductory comments, and then Brian will address business results and comment on the overall financial position.
As part of today’s call, I would like to direct you to our Web site www.sunocoinc.com, where we have posted a number of presentation slides, which may provide a useful reference as we progress through our remarks.
I’d also refer you to the Safe Harbor statement referenced in slide two of the slide package and is included in the afternoon’s earnings release. Now, let’s begin.
In the third quarter, we faced the challenging market environment, particularly in the Northeast. Excess supply, pressures margins which deteriorated from second quarter level.
In addition, rising crude cost at the end of the quarter (inaudible) our results. However, our year-over-year third quarter results which had comparable market conditions in those periods improved significantly, thanks to the actions that we have taken to address the business systems within our control.
As you can see from slides three and four, we earned $27 million in net income excluding special items or $0.22 per share. There are three aspects of our performance this quarter that I would like to review. First, I will cover the fuels business, particularly in Retail and Logistics, which together earned $110 million in pre-tax income during the quarter. These are strong businesses that are generating significant value today and which present promising opportunities for continued growth.
During the third quarter, Sunoco Logistics Partners L.P. closed on the purchase of additional ownership interests in three pipeline joint ventures. These news added immediate value to both Sunoco and Sunoco Logistics and we continue to evaluate other opportunities for growth, in both of these businesses.
Continuing with the fuels business, Refining and Supply posted a loss of $70 million pre-tax in the quarter. We faced deterioration in market margins, which at least temporarily overshadowed our ongoing work in the controllable areas of our business.
Market conditions in the third quarter demonstrated that, we continue to face challenges in this business segment; however, I call your attention to the fact that in Refining and Supply we are near breakeven on a year-to-date basis compared to last year, that’s an improvement of approximately $285 million pre-tax.
Now, we’re certainly not satisfied with breakeven performance, but that kind of improvement reflects the progress we have made. We expect that the fourth quarter will be at least as challenging as the first three quarters of 2010, and accordingly, we have maintained focus on the fundamentals of safety and reliability margin capture and maintaining competitive cost structure.
The second aspect of our performance that I will cover is the coke business which had a strong quarter and earned $44 million of pre-tax income. We benefited from strong operations and the positive market conditions.
Coke’s continued to set the stage for promising future as a standalone business. In addition, we continue to see strong growth opportunities for coke both in U.S and internationally over the next 10 or more years.
Finally, the third element of the quarter that I’ll touch on is the strength of our balance sheet which Brian will talk about in more detail later. Our cash balance continues to be healthy and our debt position is strong at approximately $175 million, excluding Sunoco Logistics.
At the end of the third quarter, our net debt to capital ratio for Sunoco excluding SXL was 6% as compared to 39% at the same time last year. Our improvement over time is evident and we will continue protecting our balance sheet going forward.
As the third quarter market environment has demonstrated, we expect market conditions for petroleum and chemical products to remain challenging, demand is weak, product inventories across the industry are high and margins are still under pressure.
We’re working hard to further lower or break even cost per barrel so that we’re able to generate cash in difficult times. We’re focused on sustaining the progress we’ve made since margin capture and we’re going to continue to run our refinery safely and reliably at optimal capacity utilization.
Focus on the fundamentals of our business will get us through the rest of the current down cycle in refining and it’s delivering to shareholders on the promise of our brand and logistics led future in the fuels business and a separate company Sunoco Energy that we’re preparing for.
Let me now turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported pretax income of $95 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in Q3, which included $62 million of pretax net favorable speci
componenttext:
Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported pretax income of $95 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in Q3, which included $62 million of pretax net favorable special items.
The special items were primarily associated with pension settlement losses, employee terminations and related costs in connection with the business improvement initiative, a gain on an MTBE insurance settlement and a non-cash gain related to an acquisition accounting at Sunoco Logistics.
While we’ve delivered another strong quarter in our Retail, Logistics and Coke businesses, we continued to face challenging marketing conditions in our Refining and Supply business.
As seen in slide four, Refining and Supply recorded a pretax loss of $70 million as excess supply and continued low demand pressured market cracks further downward from the prior quarter. While we are certainly not satisfied in posting a loss in our Refining and Supply business, the business did improve its pretax income by $112 million as compared to the same quarter of last year when market conditions were fairly similar to this quarter.
We feel confident that this significant improvement is to a large degree the result of actions we have taken including the closure of the Eagle Point refinery, that focused on reliability and optimization of our plants, reengineering our market strategy and last but not least our initiatives around costs structure. Our sharp focus on achieving a competitive cost structure continuously yield results.
Year-to-date cash operating expenses through the third quarter excluding fuel utilities and discontinued operations were approximately $170 million lower than the prior years, excluding the Coke business where we’re adding cost as we grow and prepare for separation, the improvement versus prior year is approximately $200 million.
This expense measure of cash operating expenses x fuel and utilities is used internally to track our progress in reducing our controllable expenses and is also part of our executive compensation target and demonstrates our efforts and success in driving our cost to a competitive level.
A year ago when we announced our decision to close the Eagle Point refinery, we communicated our goal to achieve breakeven cash flow in our Refining and Supply business even within a tough market environment like we were experiencing at the time.
As a result of the actions we have taken, on a year-to-date basis we have free cash flow breakeven in our Refining and Supply business excluding working capital changes. And in the fourth quarter of 2010, we expect to generate significant cash through the permanent liquidation of inventories largely related to the closure of the Eagle Point refinery.
So we plan to achieve positive cash flow in Refining and Supply in 2010 following a substantial decline in the market during the fourth quarter. This reflects the significant improvement in the Refining and Supply business as compared to last year when the business experienced a significant cash burn.
So while we continue to be pleased with our progress in many of the controllable aspects of our operations, it is evident that the market will continue to present significant challenges and we maintain focus on the fundamentals to ensure we are competitive with our assets.
Regarding our Q3 business unit results, I direct you to slide four through eight. Specifically, Retail Marketing earned $68 million pre-tax in the third quarter of 2010, while retail gasoline margins were below the strong periods of second quarter and the prior year, they were still relatively strong despite the overall rise in wholesale gasoline prices during the period which typically pressures retail margins.
As compared to the same quarter of the prior year, gasoline and distillate volumes were up about 1% and 8% respectively on an open both years basis. Additionally, we continue to evaluate acquisition opportunities and we have been successful at growing our distributor business incrementally adding net 86 sites store network during the third quarter. At the end of the third quarter, 4,829 total sites carry the Sunoco flag and we want to grow that further.
Logistics earned $42 million pre-tax and Sunoco Logistics Partners continues to be a reliable and ratable source of earning to a Sunoco. The throughput in terminalling business has proven to be a ratable and growing business and is supplemented by crude oil market opportunities when contango market structures exist.
During the third quarter, we closed on the purchase of three pipeline interests that are immediately accretive to earnings and we continue to believe there are additional positive growth opportunities in the future. Sunoco Logistics Partners is projecting over $435 million in total capital expenditures in 2010, including both organic and acquisition projects.
As we mentioned in our Q2 earnings call, Sunoco has facilitated some of this growth via $100 million intercompany loan to Sunoco Logistics that occurred in Q3 and was one of the primary reasons that our cash balance is lower in Q3 versus Q2.
Coke posted another solid contribution, earning $44 million pre-tax in Q3. During the third quarter, we operated well at all of our facilities including our Granite City facility, which started operation late last year. We also benefited during this period from spot sales of coke production from the 2009 downturn.
At this time we maintain our full-year guidance for SunCoke net income at $125 million to $140 million in net income as we expect expenses to be higher from investments in growth and separation planning and no spot Coke sales in Q4.
As shown on slide six, Refining and Supply had a loss of $70 million pre-tax in the third quarter of 2010 compared to a loss of $182 million pretax in the same quarter of 2009. If you’ll recall, last quarter were the first quarter that we generated profits for refining and supply since the first quarter of 2009.
In our last quarterly call, we said that while there were market factors that contributed to our strong performance, our actions to improve margin capture, cost position and reliability were significant factors in achieving profitable results.
In the third quarter, market conditions deteriorated, particularly in the Northeast. For the aspects of our business that are under our control, we largely performed well, although we did experience some operational issues that will impact our performance in the fourth quarter.
Operationally, we achieved the crude unit utilization rate of 94%, higher than last quarter and in line with our plan. However our system-wide ultra low sulfur diesel production was down by approximately 4,000 barrels per day from the second quarter due to some operational issues.
With respect to our Q3 margins realizations, I refer you to slide seven and eight for more detail on a refining system crude cost and product differentials versus our benchmark. Our third quarter results reflect significant improvement versus the same quarter of the prior year.
As we indicated that last quarter’s conference call we are capturing more than benchmark margin that is available to us and this is evident again this quarter in the year-over-year improvement.
While there are a number of factors that affect our realizations versus our benchmarks, which are market related, we have taken actions on identified opportunities to improve our margin realizations versus benchmark margins, and we continue to see the benefit from these actions.
As you can see on slide seven, our refine-wide, Refining and Supply benchmark averaged $4.87 per barrel for the third quarter, only about $0.30 better than the same quarter of last year. However our margin capture of 80% was significantly improved from Q3 ‘09 margin capture of 60% and excluding the negative impact of crude timing, margin capture for the third quarter of 2010 was 90%.
The significant improvement in margin capture versus last year can be attributed to improve the liability and a successful strategy in matching operations to the market opportunities. Improvement liability in utilization is both in the Northeast and Toledo.
Overall as compared to last year, we benefited from higher overall distillate and ULSD production as a percent of total production. In Q3 2010 37% of our net production was distillate versus 33% in Q3 ‘09 with the offset in less of the cheaper residual fuel.
Our actions that supported this improvement include the closure of Eagle Point, adjustments in our crude slate and the operation of the new hydrocracker unit in Philadelphia. Within the distillate pool, we are operating more of the distillate for ULSD versus last year and Northeast ULSD differentials to heating oil have wind by more than $0.02 a gallon quarter-over-quarter.
Using second quarter 2010 as a basis, benchmark margins and margin caps declined in the third quarter and shows us that even with the improvement from last year we have more work to do on cost reduction and margin capture. Benchmark margins fell by $1.65 per barrel on average as neither gasoline prices nor distillate prices kept up with the rise in crude costs.
Realized margins were $3.88 per barrel resulting in a margin capture of 80% versus 113% in the second quarter. The biggest driver of this decline in margin capture from the second quarter to the third quarter was within crude differentials and largely due to market conditions namely rising crude prices.
Our crude costs for the quarter averaged about $0.92 per barrel above our weighted benchmark and approximately $0.50 of the $0.92 related to the timing of our crude prices.
This factor is a complete reversal from the prior year when crude prices were falling and timing actually provided a benefit to our realized margins. As a reminder, our crude purchases in the Northeast price in a lag and the price of crude rose during the quarter and particularly during the lag period of pricing in the first five days of October. Excluding the impact of crude timing in either quarter, margin capture dropped from approximately 104% in Q2 to approximately 90% in Q3.
On the product side, our average differential was approximately $0.07 per barrel below our weighted benchmark. While this is a bit drop off from a very strong Q2 performance as you compare to the last several periods you will see that it was dramatically improved and reflects our focus on improving our reliability and placing our production through the most profitable channels.
Relative to Q2, the product realizations were challenged by a falling gasoline market. In the third quarter, the gasoline track in the Northeast declined by almost $4 per barrel from the prior quarter.
Additionally, we did not get the same lift in realized margin and margin capture from value-added products as premium and RBOB differentials to conventional gasoline also narrowed substantially. In the period of rising absolute prices, petrochemical and other non-tracked product prices were not able to keep pace with the rising and volatile benchmark prices.
Lastly, and the factor that was most within our control, the ULSD production in the Northeast complex dropped from the second quarter levels due to operational issues.
In summary, we still feel confident that we are executing on many of the factors within our control, both operational and how we are approaching the market. As we noted last quarter, there can be market factors which affect our margin capture rate in any given reported period as was the case this quarter. We remain focused on the fundamentals and those elements within our control that drives our performance in whatever environment exists.
During the fourth quarter, we will be performing maintenance in our Northeast system. Additionally, our crude throughput in Toledo will be negatively impacted by pipeline allocations that resulted from the End Bridge line interruptions. Accordingly, we expect challenged Refining and Supply results in Q4 given the resulting and low utilization level and weak market conditions.
Finally, let me take a few minutes to discuss our financial position at the end of the quarter. In conjunction with that, I direct you to slides nine and 10. From a funds flow perspective, our third quarter net cash flow before debt activity at Sunoco, excluding Sunoco Logistics was used up approximately $327 million.
We ended the quarter with a net debt position of approximately $175 million excluding Sunoco Logistics. The sequential cash decline in the quarter was driven by working capital movements and the loan of $100 million by Sunoco to Sunoco Logistics that help supported the acquisition of Texon, a butane-blending business. We ended the quarter with a net debt-to-capital ratio of 6% at the Sunoco level excluding Sunoco Logistics.
At September 30, we had $1.1 billion of cash and approximately $1.5 billion of available committed boring capacity as Sunoco excluding Sunoco Logistics. As reflected in our balance sheet, our financial position and liquidity continues to be very strong. Additionally, in the fourth quarter 2010, we do plan to generate cash flow through the permanent liquidation of inventories that primarily relate Eagle Point closure.
As we look forward to the remaining months of 2010 and into 2011, we will continue to take appropriate actions that will assist us in maintaining our financial flexibility to pursue attractive opportunities in our growth businesses, as well as ride out the refining downturn.
As an update to our capital plans for 2010, our latest planned capital spending for Refining and Supply in 2010 is approximately $225 million, about $50 million less than we last guided in June. This reduction has been achieved primarily due to cost efficiencies in projects as well some deferred projects which have no impact on safe and reliable operations.
There are no other changes to our 2010 capital guidance at this point in time. For 2011, our planned capital spending for Refining and Supply is between $225 million and $250 million, in line with current year spend and below DD&A.
A final balance sheet note related to inventory, at September 30, the current replacement cost of all inventories valued at LIFO exceeds their carrying value by $2.8 billion.
I will take a few minutes to provide an update on our plans to separate SunCoke. As we have said, this planned separation is part of a strategy to unlock shareholder value and maximize the future success of both Sunoco and SunCoke. We still plan to effect the separation in the first half of 2011 and are in the process of evaluating the appropriate form of separation.
During the third quarter, we announced the hiring of Fritz Henderson to lead the separated SunCoke business. We also announced that the business will relocate after the separation to a city more internationally accessible with the preferred location being Chicago.
Most recently, in late October we filed our IRS private letter ruling requesting a tax free separation. We continue to work through the other aspects of the separation process including any filings that would be necessary if SunCoke were to be a separate public company.
As you can see we are moving steadily down the path of separation in the first half of 2011 and we will share more information when we are able to within the confines of the process.
So, in closing to build a better Sunoco and to deliver value to shareholders, we remain focused on the fundamentals running our refineries safely and reliably at optimal capacity, lowering our breakeven cost per barrel and furthering the progress we have made in capturing available margin.
This focus in continued investment in our brand and ability to serve customers will help us achieve our aspiration of becoming the preferred provider of transportation of fuels in our markets.
With that I’ll ask the operator to open the line for any questions you may have.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) And our first question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America. Your line is open.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) And our first question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America. Your line is open.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Just a couple of quick ones here. Are you able to quantify the potential value of the inventory that you are trying to liquidate? And my follow-up is a capital question. So it looks like CapEx has come down obviously in the Refining business be
componenttext: Thank you. Just a couple of quick ones here. Are you able to quantify the potential value of the inventory that you are trying to liquidate? And my follow-up is a capital question. So it looks like CapEx has come down obviously in the Refining business below depreciation levels. What does that mean in terms of the carrying book value you have the refining system? Is that a sustainable situation and I guess if you could quantify also any downtime/maintenance funds that you have both in the fourth quarter and through next year, that will be great? Thanks.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, Doug, I’ll try to punch through these. So when we announced the closure of Eagle Point we said that we would take out roughly between $250 million and $300 million of inventory related to that. We took about half of that out in the fourth quarter
componenttext:
Okay, Doug, I’ll try to punch through these. So when we announced the closure of Eagle Point we said that we would take out roughly between $250 million and $300 million of inventory related to that. We took about half of that out in the fourth quarter of last year and so as we get through the fourth quarter, we would be somewhere in the range of the second half of that, it may move up and down a little bit based upon market conditions and things that are going on in the operations, but that’s kind of broadly the magnitude of the second half of that inventory reduction which is as you said would be permanent.
The second question with regard to CapEx, and the CapEx being in Refining (inaudible) below DD&A, at this time we’re only giving guidance for 2011 which is obviously below DD&A and what I would say is that over the last few years Sunoco had invested a lot of capital in the refining assets for various consent fees and another projects and so you need to put the current capital spend against DD&A and CD&A in the context of the kind of projects in particular consent decree projects that were done over the recent past.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on potential downtime, can you give some guidance on maintenance over the next year and a half?
componenttext: Okay. And on potential downtime, can you give some guidance on maintenance over the next year and a half?

componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Lynn. On 2011, at Philadelphia, we’re planning a reformer turnaround and some of sulfur unit market took reformer LNG to lead on those (Technical difficulty) reformer and asset trader, and that’s where the unit turnarounds are.

componenttextpreview: Okay. If I heard you right, and please confirm this, the additional retail outlets that are now in the station count are distributor outlets. And I guess I am a little bit curious as to what the perceived advantage of expanding the distributor channel is
componenttext: Okay. If I heard you right, and please confirm this, the additional retail outlets that are now in the station count are distributor outlets. And I guess I am a little bit curious as to what the perceived advantage of expanding the distributor channel is to you?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, we’ve said all along that we think it’s good to have growth in all the classes to trade in retail and even if it’s a distributor, they have a contract with us, it provides more ratable off-take, more plantable off-take for us, and it’s a hig
componenttext: Mark, we’ve said all along that we think it’s good to have growth in all the classes to trade in retail and even if it’s a distributor, they have a contract with us, it provides more ratable off-take, more plantable off-take for us, and it’s a higher netback channel than if we just put it into the unbranded business. So, we are actually looking to grow all of our branded business, all classes of trades, and to have a nice mix between those in which we’re heavily invested and the distributor trade which we have less so.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you move anything in the unbranded channel now?
componenttext: Do you move anything in the unbranded channel now?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we produce gasoline that not at all going to the branded channel. If you take it on a system’s basis, I think it’s about 84% of the volume in gasoline is going into branded channels and the rest of the production is into unbranded channels.
componenttext: Yes, we produce gasoline that not at all going to the branded channel. If you take it on a system’s basis, I think it’s about 84% of the volume in gasoline is going into branded channels and the rest of the production is into unbranded channels.

componenttext: No, not anything that we are able to disclose. We continue to have meetings with both producers, potential customers and of course, our partner, and we are working on engineering for that project that would allow us to be in a better position to disclose the capital spending around it. So, we are moving along, but we don’t really have anything more material to discuss at this time.

componenttext: No, I think Mark, I think the only thing we would say is that as a separate company, we’ll make sure that they have a balance sheet and the capital structure and active capital that’s appropriate for the industry they are in and the growth profile that they have in front of them.

componenttext: Sure, so when we given our guidance there were some layering in of coke contract which affected the guidance as it spread first half, first to second half. componenttext: Good afternoon. Brian, I appreciate the detailed comments on the margin capture in your opening remarks. My question is regarding coke and as I look at prices that were available in the marketplace this time last year versus this year, there is $75 to $100 a ton improvement in met coal pricing. Just using your metrics on a $25 a ton converts to about $20 million a year net income and then you add in a partial year of Middleton, it seems 2011 coke net income should comfortably be over $200 million. Am I doing my math right?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, Jeff, you are doing your math right. We’ve yet to lock in our contract prices for 2011. We also tax credits that are factored in our net income. At this point, we do see fairly ratable tax credit in 2011 versus 2010.
componenttext: I would say, Jeff, you are doing your math right. We’ve yet to lock in our contract prices for 2011. We also tax credits that are factored in our net income. At this point, we do see fairly ratable tax credit in 2011 versus 2010.

componenttext: I would say there was no notable change in our feedstock volumes. We had pretty consistent crude site. What we did say was the quality differentials of the light sweet riding out of it. There seem to be some increased demand globally for the light sweet in the third quarter.

componenttext: Well, Paul we don’t disclose individual plant profitability. It is a $380 million project and these projects are designed to return above cost of capital returns. headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good evening. Welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call where we will discuss the company's third quarter earnings that were reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McGrory, Man
componenttext:
Thank you, and good evening. Welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call where we will discuss the company's third quarter earnings that were reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McGrory, Manager of Investor Relations. I'll start by making a few introductory comments, and then Brian will address business results and comment on the overall financial position. 
As part of today's call, I'd like to direct you to our website, www.sunocoinc.com, where we have posted a number of presentation slides, which may provide a useful reference as we progress through our remarks. I would also refer you to the Safe Harbor statement referenced in Slide 2 of the Slide package that is included in the afternoon's earnings release. 
Now let's begin. In the third quarter, we faced a challenging market environment, particularly in the Northeast. Excess supply pressured margins, which deteriorated from second quarter levels. In addition, rising crude costs at the end of the quarter hurt our results. However, our year-over-year third quarter results which have comparable market conditions in both periods improved significantly, thanks to the actions that we have taken to address the business which is in our control. 
As you can see from Slides 3 and 4, we earned $27 million in net income, excluding special items or $0.22 per share. There are three aspects of our performance this quarter that I would like to review. First, I will cover the Fuels business, particularly Retail and Logistics, which together earned $110 million in pretax income during the quarter. These are strong businesses that are generating significant value today, and which present promising opportunities for continued growth. 
During the third quarter, Sunoco Logistics Partners L.P. closed on the purchase of additional ownership interest in three pipeline joint ventures. These moves added immediate value to both Sunoco and Sunoco Logistics. And we continue to evaluate other opportunities for growth in both of these businesses. 
Continuing with the Fuels business, Refining and Supply posted a loss of $70 million pretax in the quarter. We face deterioration in market margins, which at least temporarily overshadowed our ongoing work on the controllable areas of our business. Market conditions in the third quarter demonstrated that we continue to face challenges in the business segment. However, I call your attention to the fact that in Refining and Supply, we are near breakeven on a year-to-date basis compared to last year, that's an improvement of approximately $285 million pretax. 
Now we're certainly not satisfied with break-even performance, but that kind of improvement reflects the progress we've made. We expect that the fourth quarter will be at least as challenging as the first three quarters of 2010. And accordingly, we've maintained focus on the fundamentals of safety and reliability, margin capture and maintaining a competitive cost structure. 
The second aspect of our performance that I'll cover is the Coke business, which had a strong quarter and earned $44 million of pretax income. We benefited from strong operations in a positive market condition. Coke’s continued success sets the stage for a promising future as a stand-alone business. In addition, we continue to see strong growth opportunities for Coke both in the U.S. and internationally over the next 10 or more years. 
Finally, the third element of the quarter that I will touch on is the strength of our balance sheet, which Brian will talk about in more detail later. Our cash balance continues to be healthy and our debt position is strong at approximately $175 million, excluding Sunoco Logistics. 
At the end of the third quarter, our net debt to capital ratio for Sunoco, excluding SXL, was 6% as compared to 39% at the same time last year. Our improvement over time is evident and we will continue protecting our balance sheet going forward. 
As the third quarter market environment has demonstrated, we expect market conditions for petroleum and chemical products to remain challenging. Demand is weak, product inventories across the industry are high and margins are still under pressure. We're working hard to further lower our break-even cost per barrel so that we're able to generate cash in difficult times. We're focused on sustaining the progress we've made in margin capture, and we're going to continue to run our refineries safely and reliably at optimal capacity utilization. 
Focus on the fundamentals of our business will get us through the rest of the current downcycle in refining and it's delivering to shareholders on the promise of our brand and Logistics-led future in the Fuels business and a separate Coke company, SunCoke Energy that we're preparing for. Let me now turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported pretax income of $95 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in Q3, which included $62 million of pretax net favorable speci
componenttext:
Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported pretax income of $95 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in Q3, which included $62 million of pretax net favorable special items. The special items were primarily associated with pension settlement losses, employee terminations and related costs in connection with the business improvement initiative, a gain on an MTBE insurance settlement and a non-cash gain related to an acquisition accounting at Sunoco Logistics. 
While we've delivered another strong quarter in our Retail, Logistics and Coke businesses, we continue to face challenging market conditions in our Refining and Supply business. As seen on Slide 4, Refining and Supply recorded a pretax loss of $70 million as excess supply and continued low demand pressured market cracks further downward from the prior quarter. While we are certainly not satisfied in posting a loss in our Refining and Supply business, the business did improve as pretax income by $112 million as compared to the same quarter of last year when market conditions were fairly similar to this quarter. We feel confident that this significant improvement is, to a large degree, the result of actions we have taken including the closure of the Eagle Point refinery, the focus on reliability and optimization of our plants, re-engineering our market strategy, and last but not least, our initiatives around cost structure. Our sharp focus on achieving a competitive cost structure continues to yield results. 
Year-to-date cash operating expenses through the third quarter, excluding fuel, utilities and discontinued operations, were approximately $170 million lower than the prior years. Excluding the Coke business where we're adding costs as we grow and prepare for separation, the improvement versus prior year is approximately $200 million. This expense measure of cash operating expenses x fuel and utilities is used internally to track our products in reducing our controllable expenses, and is also part of our executive compensation targets and demonstrates our efforts and success in driving our costs to a competitive level. 
A year ago, when we announced our decision to close the Eagle Point refinery, we communicated our goal to achieve breakeven cash flow in our Refining and Supply business even within a tough market environment like we were experiencing at the time. As a result of the actions we have taken, on a year-to-date basis, we are free cash flow breakeven in our Refining and Supply business, excluding working capital changes. And in the fourth quarter of 2010, we expect to generate significant cash through the permanent liquidation of inventories, largely related to the closure of the Eagle Point refinery. So we plan to achieve positive cash flow in Refining and Supply in 2010, barring a substantial decline in the market during the fourth quarter. This reflects a significant improvement in the Refining and Supply business as compared to last year when the business experienced a significant cash burn. So while we continue to be pleased with our progress in many of the controllable aspects of our operations, it is evident that the market will continue to present significant challenges and we maintain focus on the fundamentals to ensure we are competitive with our assets. 
Regarding our Q3 business unit results, I direct you to Slides 4 through 8. Specifically, Retail Marketing earned $68 million pretax in the third quarter of 2010, while retail gasoline margins were below the strong periods of second quarter and the prior year, they were still relatively strong despite the overall rise in wholesale gasoline prices during the period, which typically pressures retail margins. 
As compared to the same quarter of the prior year, gasoline and distillate volumes were up about 1% and 8%, respectively on an open both years basis. Additionally, we continue to evaluate acquisition opportunities, and we have been successful at growing our Distributor business incrementally adding net 86 sites to our network during the third quarter. At the end of the third quarter, 4,829 total sites carried the Sunoco flag, and we want to grow that further. 
Logistics earned $42 million pretax as Sunoco Logistics Partners continues to be a reliable and ratable source of earnings for Sunoco. The throughput in terminaling business has proven to be a ratable and growing business and is supplemented by crude oil market opportunities when contango market structures exist. 
During the third quarter, we closed on the purchase of three pipeline interests that are immediately accretive to earnings, and we continue to believe there are additional positive growth opportunities in the future. Sunoco Logistics Partners is projecting over $435 million in total capital expenditures in 2010, including both organic and acquisition projects. 
As we mentioned in our Q2 earnings call, Sunoco has facilitated some of this growth via $100 million intercompany loan to Sunoco Logistics that occurred in Q3 and was one of the primary reasons that our cash balance is lower in Q3 versus Q2. 
Coke posted another solid contribution earning $44 million pretax in Q3. During the third quarter, we operated well at all of our facilities, including our Granite City facility, which started operations late last year. We also benefited during this period from spot sales of Coke production from the 2009 downturn. At this time, we maintain our full year guidance for SunCoke net income at $125 million to $140 million in net income as we expect expenses to be higher from investments in growth and separation planning and no spot Coke sales in Q4. 
As shown on Slide 6, Refining and Supply had a loss of $70 million pretax in the third quarter 2010 compared to a loss of $182 million pretax in the same quarter of 2009. If you recall, last quarter was the first quarter that we generated profits for Refining and Supply since the first quarter of 2009. In our last quarterly call, we said that while there were market factors that contributed to our strong performance, our actions to improve margin capture, cost position and reliability were significant factors in achieving profitable results. 
In the third quarter, market conditions deteriorated particularly in the Northeast. For the aspects of our business that are under our control, we largely performed well, although we did experience some operational issues that will impact our performance in the fourth quarter. Operationally, we achieved a crude unit utilization rate of 94%, higher than last quarter and in line with our plan. However, our systemwide Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel production was down by approximately 4,000 barrels per day from the second quarter due to some operational issues. 
With respect to our Q3 margin realizations, I refer you to Slides 7 and 8 for more detail on the refining system crude costs and product differentials versus our benchmark. Our third quarter results reflect significant improvement versus the same quarter of the prior year. As we indicated at last quarter's conference call, we are capturing more of the benchmark margin that is available to us and this is evident again this quarter in the year-over-year improvement. While there are a number of factors that affect our realizations versus our benchmarks, which are market-related, we have taken actions on identified opportunities to improve our margin realizations versus benchmark margins, and we continue to see the benefits from these actions. 
As you can see on Slide 7, our refining-wide, Refining and Supply benchmark averaged $4.87 per barrel for the third quarter, only about $0.30 better than the same quarter of last year. However, our margin capture of 80% was significantly improved from Q3 '09 margin capture of 60%. And excluding the negative impact of crude timing, margin capture for the third quarter of 2010 was 90%. The significant improvement in margin capture versus last year can be attributed to improved reliability and a successful strategy matching operations to market opportunities. The improved reliability in utilization is both in the Northeast and Toledo. Overall, as compared to last year, we benefited from higher overall distillate and ULSD production as a percent of total production. 
In Q3 2010, 37% of our net production was distillate versus 33% in Q3 '09 with the offset in less of the cheaper residual field. Our actions that supported this improvement include the closure of Eagle Point, adjustments in our crudes play and the operation of the new hydrocracker unit in Philadelphia. Within the distillate pool, we are operating more of the distillate ULSD versus last year and Northeast ULSD differentials for heating oil have wind [ph] by more than $0.02 a gallon quarter-over-quarter. 
Using second quarter 2010 as a basis, benchmark margins and margin capture declined in the third quarter and shows us that even with the improvement from last year, we have more work to do on cost reduction and margin capture. Benchmark margins fell by $1.65 per barrel on average as neither gasoline prices nor distillate prices kept up with the rising crude cost. Realized margins were $3.88 per barrel, resulting in a margin capture of 80% versus 113% in the second quarter. The biggest driver in this decline in margin capture from the second quarter to the third quarter was within crude differentials, and largely due to market conditions, namely rising crude prices. 
Our crude cost for the quarter averaged about $0.92 per barrel above our weighted benchmark and approximately $0.50 of the $0.92 relates to the timing of our crude prices. This factor is a complete reversal from the prior quarter when crude prices were falling and timing actually provided a benefit to our realized margins. As a reminder, our crude purchases in the Northeast priced on a lag and the price of crude rose during the quarter, in particular during the lag period of pricing in the first five days of October. 
Excluding the impact of crude timing in either quarter, margin capture dropped from approximately 104% in Q2 to approximately 90% in Q3. On the product side, our average differential was approximately $0.07 per barrel below our weighted benchmark. While this did drop off from a very strong Q2 performance, as you compare it to the last several periods, you will see that it was dramatically improved and reflects our focus on improving our reliability and placing our production through the most profitable channels. 
Relative to Q2, the product realizations were challenged by a falling gasoline market. In the third quarter, the gasoline crack in the Northeast declined by almost $4 per barrel from the prior quarter. Additionally, we did not get the same lift in realized margin and margin capture from value-added products as premium and [inaudible] differentials to conventional gasoline also narrowed substantially. 
In the period of rising absolute prices, petrochemical and other non-crack product prices were not able to keep pace with the rising and volatile benchmark prices. Lastly and the factor that was most within our control, the ULSD production at the Northeast complex dropped, from the second quarter levels due to operational issues. In summary, we still feel confident that we're executing on many of the factors within our control, both operational and how we are approaching the market. As we noted last quarter, there can be market factors which affect our margin capture rate in any given reporting period as was the case this quarter. We remain focused on the fundamentals and those elements within our control to drive strong performance in whatever environment exists. 
So in the fourth quarter, we will be performing maintenance in our Northeast system. Additionally our crude throughput in Toledo will be negatively impacted by pipeline allocations that resulted from the Enbridge line interruptions. Accordingly, we expect challenge Refining and Supply results in Q4, given the resulting low-utilization level and weak market conditions. 
Finally, let me take a few minutes to discuss our financial position at the end of the quarter. In conjunction with that, I direct you to Slides 9 and 10. From a funds flow perspective, our third quarter net cash flow before debt activity at Sunoco, excluding Sunoco Logistics, was the use of approximately $327 million. We ended the quarter with a net debt position of approximately $175 million, excluding Sunoco Logistics. The sequential cash decline in the quarter was driven by working capital movements and the loan of $100 million by Sunoco to Sunoco Logistics to help support its acquisition of Texon, a Butane Blending business. We ended the quarter with a net debt to capital ratio of 6% at the Sunoco level, excluding Sunoco Logistics. 
At September 30, we had $1.1 billion of cash and approximately $1.5 billion of available committed borrowing capacity at Sunoco, excluding Sunoco Logistics. As reflected in our balance sheet, our financial position and liquidity continues to be very strong. Additionally, in the fourth quarter of 2010, we do plan to generate cash flow through the permanent liquidation of inventory that primarily relates to Eagle Point closure. As we look forward to the remaining months of 2010 and into 2011, we will continue to take appropriate actions that will assist us in maintaining our financial flexibility to pursue attractive opportunities in our growth businesses, as well as ride out the refining downturn. 
As an update to our capital plans for 2010, our latest planned capital spending for Refining and Supply in 2010 is approximately $225 million, about $50 million less than we last guided in June. This reduction has been achieved primarily due to cost efficiencies in projects as well as some deferred projects which have no impact on safe and reliable operations. There are no other changes to our 2010 capital guidance at this point in time. 
For 2011, our planned capital spending for Refining and Supply is between $225 million and $250 million in line with current year spend and below DD&A. 
A final balance sheet note related to inventory. At September 30, the current replacement cost of all inventories valued at LIFO exceeds their carrying value by $2.8 billion. I'll take a few minutes to provide an update on our plans to separate SunCoke. As we have said, this planned separation is part of a strategy to unlock shareholder value and maximize the future success of both Sunoco and SunCoke. We still plan to affect the separation in the first half of 2011 and are in the process of evaluating the appropriate form of separation. 
During the third quarter, we announced the hiring of Fritz Henderson to lead the separated SunCoke business. We also announced that the business will relocate after the separation to a city more internationally accessible with the preferred location being Chicago. Most recently in late October, we filed our IRS private letter ruling requesting a tax re-separation. We continue to work through the other aspects of the separation process, including any filings that would be necessary if SunCoke were to be a separate public company. As you can see we are moving steadily down the path to separation in the first half of 2011, and we will share more information when we are able to within the confines of the process. 
So in closing, to build a better Sunoco and to deliver value to shareholders, we remain focused on the fundamentals: Running our refineries safely and reliably in optimal capacity; lowering our break-even cost per barrel; and furthering the progress we have made in capturing available margin. This focus in continued investment in our brand and ability to serve customers will help us achieve our aspiration of becoming the preferred provider of transportation fuels in our markets. 
With that, I'll ask the operator to open the lines for any questions you may have.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are you able to quantify the potential value of the inventory that you plan to liquidate? And my follow-up is a capital question. So it looks like CapEx has come down obviously in the Refining business below depreciation levels. What does that mean in ter
componenttext: Are you able to quantify the potential value of the inventory that you plan to liquidate? And my follow-up is a capital question. So it looks like CapEx has come down obviously in the Refining business below depreciation levels. What does that mean in terms of the carrying value, or the carrying book value you have for the refining system? Is that a sustainable situation? And I guess if you could quantify also any downtimes/maintenance plans that you have both in the fourth quarter and through the next year, that would be great.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, Doug. I'll try to punch through these. So when we announced the closure of Eagle Point, we said that we would take out roughly between $250 million and $300 million of inventory related to that. We took about half of that out in the fourth quarter o
componenttext: Okay, Doug. I'll try to punch through these. So when we announced the closure of Eagle Point, we said that we would take out roughly between $250 million and $300 million of inventory related to that. We took about half of that out in the fourth quarter of last year. And so as we get through the fourth quarter, we’d be somewhere in the range of the second half of that, it may move up and down a little bit based upon market conditions and things that are going on in the operations, but that's kind of broadly the magnitude of the second half of that inventory reduction, which as we said, would be permanent. The second question with regard to CapEx, and the CapEx being in refining below the DD&A, at this time, we're only giving guidance for 2011 which is obviously below DD&A. And what I would say is that over the last few years, Sunoco had invested a lot of capital in the refining assets for various consent decrees and other projects. So you need to put the current capital spend against DD&A in the context of the kind of projects in particular consent decree projects that were done over the recent past.

componenttext: Mark, we have said all along that we think it's good to have growth in all the classes of trade in retail and that it helps -- even if it's a distributor, they have a contract with us, it provides more ratable off take, more plannable off take for us and is a higher net back channel than if we just put it into the unbranded business. So we're actually looking to grow all of our branded business, all across the trade and to have a nice mix between those in which we are heavily invested and the distributor trade which we're less so.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. So when we get in our guidance, it was under the context of there were some layering in of coal contracts which affected the guidance as it spread first half versus the second half. So we had guided that relative to our full year guidance, about 40%
componenttext: Sure. So when we get in our guidance, it was under the context of there were some layering in of coal contracts which affected the guidance as it spread first half versus the second half. So we had guided that relative to our full year guidance, about 40% would be recognized in the second half. So that's kind of the first factor that you need to consider. Relative to the guidance, actually 3Q ended up a little better than we expected because of the spot sales that I mentioned earlier and that was probably the largest factor that we saw in 3Q to speak of.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of your current balance of NOLs and capital losses, where do you guys stand year-to-date?
componenttext: In terms of your current balance of NOLs and capital losses, where do you guys stand year-to-date?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have sort of moved into starting to pay taxes again. We had significant NOLs and refunds earlier in the year. But we are profitable this year, and so we're sort of moving back into more of a normalized cash taxpayer environment and would like to
componenttext: Well, we have sort of moved into starting to pay taxes again. We had significant NOLs and refunds earlier in the year. But we are profitable this year, and so we're sort of moving back into more of a normalized cash taxpayer environment and would like to stay there.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Jeff Dietert your line is open, with Simmons.
componenttext: Next question comes from Jeff Dietert your line is open, with Simmons.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, I appreciate the detailed comments on the margin capture in your opening remarks. My question is regarding Coke. And as I look at prices that were available in the marketplace this time last year versus this year, there's a $75 to $100 a ton improv
componenttext: Brian, I appreciate the detailed comments on the margin capture in your opening remarks. My question is regarding Coke. And as I look at prices that were available in the marketplace this time last year versus this year, there's a $75 to $100 a ton improvement in met coal pricing just using your metrics on a $25 a ton converts to about $20 million a year net income. And then you add in a partial year of Middletown, it seems 2011 Coke net income should comfortably be over $200 million. Am I doing my math right?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, Jeff, you're doing your math right. And we're obviously, we've yet to lock in our contract prices for 2011, and we also have tax credit that are factored in our net income. At this point, we do see fairly ratable tax credits in 2011 versus 20
componenttext: I would say, Jeff, you're doing your math right. And we're obviously, we've yet to lock in our contract prices for 2011, and we also have tax credit that are factored in our net income. At this point, we do see fairly ratable tax credits in 2011 versus 2010.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about any changes in feedstock during the third quarter? Doba volumes, volumes tied to Bonny versus Brent, especially in the Northeast refining?
componenttext: Could you talk about any changes in feedstock during the third quarter? Doba volumes, volumes tied to Bonny versus Brent, especially in the Northeast refining?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say there was no notable change in our feedstock volumes lately. It’s a pretty consistent crude slate. What we did see was the quality differentials for the light sweet widening out a bit as there seemed to be some increased demand globally for
componenttext: I would say there was no notable change in our feedstock volumes lately. It’s a pretty consistent crude slate. What we did see was the quality differentials for the light sweet widening out a bit as there seemed to be some increased demand globally for the light sweet in the third quarter.

componenttext: Yes, Paul. That law suit has not had any impact on the Q3 financial results. And the suit, if you will, is going through the judicial process.

componenttext: Well, as you know, these things sort of move back and forth as you go through the various parts of the process. Right now, we are scheduled for trial in late Q1, early Q2 of next year.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: And Brian, is there a rule of thumb, because I know that the number is going to be swinging a lot and over the map on the company charges going forward. What would be a reasonable trending level that we should assume?

componenttext: Paul, this is Clare. What you're seeing now in the third quarter is the best I can give you in terms of guidance. What can swing that – it’s a relatively small base, so it can swing somewhat fairly easily and what can swing that is depending on what we're doing now performance-wise and what kind of success sharing flows through there. Also, we have some tax adjustments to creditor or whatsoever retroactively or otherwise that can flow through there. But I'd say 3Q at this point is as normal as you can get.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would also say, Paul, that we continue to be very focused on taking down costs across the company, including the overhead costs.
componenttext: I would also say, Paul, that we continue to be very focused on taking down costs across the company, including the overhead costs.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Clare, I know that you guys is in the middle of renegotiating the METCO contract. Any kind of indication that the contract for next year comparing to this year is it going to be flat, up or down given so far what you guys can see?
componenttext: Sure. Clare, I know that you guys is in the middle of renegotiating the METCO contract. Any kind of indication that the contract for next year comparing to this year is it going to be flat, up or down given so far what you guys can see?

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the market indicators right now would suggest that the prices would be a little bit higher. But there is some softness in the market as well, and I think if you look at even recent news flow in the last week or two suggesting some softening
componenttext: Well, I think the market indicators right now would suggest that the prices would be a little bit higher. But there is some softness in the market as well, and I think if you look at even recent news flow in the last week or two suggesting some softening in those markets. So I think it's a little too early to say, Paul. Until things are contracted, they're not contracted and we've got to work through that, certainly be able to give you a better perspective next quarter.

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Sunoco Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Paul, we don't disclose individual plant profitability. It is a $380 million project and these projects are designed to return above cost of capital returns. So you can do some math off of that once the thing is up and running, and we’ve worked ou
componenttext: Well, Paul, we don't disclose individual plant profitability. It is a $380 million project and these projects are designed to return above cost of capital returns. So you can do some math off of that once the thing is up and running, and we’ve worked out any start-up issues and have it up and running, you can kind of get close enough to the profitability that, that would evolve at that time.
